hexcasting.book_description: The Hex Book, all in one place.
hexcasting.name: Hex Casting
hexcasting.description: A mod for Forge and Fabric adding stack-based programmable spellcasting, inspired by Psi.

caduceus.book_description: A Clojure-based Hex Casting addon for advanced meta-evaluation.
caduceus.name: Caduceus
caduceus.description: A Clojure-based addon for advanced meta-evaluation related to jump iotas.

complexhex.book_description: The Complex Hex Book, all in one place.
complexhex.name: Complex Hex
complexhex.description: Adds complex numbers, quaternions, BIT displays, and bubbles.

dthexcasting.book_description: The DTHexcasting Book, all in one place.
dthexcasting.name: Dynamic Trees - Hexcasting
dthexcasting.description: Makes Hex Casting compatible with Dynamic Trees, adding dynamically growing versions of the all edified trees.

ephemera.book_description: The Ephemera Book, all in one place.
ephemera.name: Ephemera
ephemera.description: An addon for Hex Casting with no particular theme.

hextrace.book_description: Hex Trace addon for Hex Casting
hextrace.name: Hex Trace
hextrace.description: Allows adding tracers to iotas to help with debugging.

hex_ars_link.book_description: The Hex-Ars Linker Book, all in one place.
hex_ars_link.name: Hex-Ars Linker
hex_ars_link.description: Link Ars Nouveau mana to Hex Casting media & cast Ars Nouveau spells inside Hex Casting.

hexdebug.book_description: The HexDebug Book, all in one place.
hexdebug.name: HexDebug
hexdebug.description: Adds items and patterns to allow debugging hexes in VSCode, and a block to make editing hexes ingame much easier.

hexflow.book_description: The HexFlow Book, all in one place.
hexflow.name: HexFlow
hexflow.description: Adds several new patterns for better control of spell executions.

hexgender.book_description: The HexGender Book, all in one place.
hexgender.name: HexGender
hexgender.description: Adds patterns for changing your gender via Wildfire's Female Gender Mod.

hexmapping.book_description: The HexMapping Book, all in one place.
hexmapping.name: HexMapping
hexmapping.description: Adds patterns to put markers on various web maps.

hexoverpowered.book_description: The HexOverpowered Book, all in one place.
hexoverpowered.name: HexOverpowered
hexoverpowered.description: Adds some OP stuff for Hex Casting.

hexparse.book_description: The HexParse Book, all in one place.
hexparse.name: HexParse
hexparse.description: Provides a pair of patterns and a set of commands to convert custom code into a list iota.

hexstruction.name: HexStruction
hexstruction.description: Adds the ability to create, manipulate, and use Structure iotas.

hextweaks.book_description: The HexTweaks Book, all in one place.
hextweaks.name: HexTweaks
hextweaks.description: Adds grand spells, rituals, and turtle casting.

hexweb.book_description: The HexWeb Book, all in one place.
hexweb.name: HexWeb
hexweb.description: Adds patterns for making HTTP requests via OkHTTP, as well as creating and manipulating JSON objects.

hexal.book_description: The Hexal Book, all in one place.
hexal.name: Hexal
hexal.description: Adds many utility patterns/spells (eg. entity health, item smelting), autonomous casting with wisps, and powerful item manipulation/storage.

hexcassettes.book_description: The Hexcassettes Book, all in one place.
hexcassettes.name: Hexcassettes
hexcassettes.description: Adds a method to delay hexes into the future, with a touch of playfulness and whimsy!

hexcellular.book_description: The Hexcellular Book, all in one place.
hexcellular.name: Hexcellular
hexcellular.description: Adds property iota to Hexcasting for easy syncing, storage, and communication of iota.

hexchanting.book_description: The Hexchanting Book, all in one place.
hexchanting.name: Hexchanting
hexchanting.description: Imbue your equipment with the power of Hex Casting.

hexic.book_description: Miscellaneous neat features and QoL patterns for Hex Casting
hexic.name: Hexic
hexic.description: Miscellaneous neat features and QoL patterns for Hex Casting.

hexical.book_description: The Hexical Book, all in one place.
hexical.name: Hexical
hexical.description: A fun addon containing genie lamps, mage blocks, specks, world scrying, and more!

hexodus.book_description: The Hexodus Book, all in one place.
hexodus.name: Hexodus
hexodus.description: A gravity addon for Hex Casting.

hexpose.book_description: The Hexpose Book, all in one place.
hexpose.name: Hexpose
hexpose.description: A library addon for Hexcasting that adds many scrying patterns and the iotas for other addons to use.

hextended.book_description: The Hextended Staves Book, all in one place.
hextended.name: Hextended Staves

hextrogen.book_description: The Hextrogen Book, all in one place.
hextrogen.name: Hextrogen

hexdim.book_description: The Hexxy Dimensions Book, all in one place.
hexdim.name: Hexxy Dimensions

hierophantics.book_description: An addon to Hex Casting that lets you work with extracted minds to create conditional hexes and merge villagers.
hierophantics.name: Hierophantics
hierophantics.description: Addon for Hex Casting that lets you work with extracted minds to create conditional hexes, merge villagers, and cast spells for less media.

ioticblocks.book_description: A port of HexGloop's block read/write patterns for 1.20.1.
ioticblocks.name: IoticBlocks
ioticblocks.description: Adds patterns for reading and writing iotas to/from blocks, and an API for addon developers to easily add iota reading/writing support to their blocks.

lapisworks.book_description: You enchanted me, therefore you must be enchanting!
lapisworks.name: Lapisworks
lapisworks.description: Harness Lapis' enchanting power with Hex Casting's media and enchant yourself.

lessertp.name: Lesser Teleport
lessertp.description: A port of Lesser Teleport from HexKinetics.

moreiotas.book_description: The MoreIotas Book, all in one place.
moreiotas.name: MoreIotas
moreiotas.description: Adds iotas for strings, matrices, types, and items.

oneironaut.book_description: The Oneironaut Book, all in one place.
oneironaut.name: Oneironaut
oneironaut.description: An addon for Hex Casting centered around exploration and use of the Noosphere.

overevaluate.book_description: The Overevaluate Book, all in one place.
overevaluate.name: Overevaluate
overevaluate.description: Adds sets and patterns for advanced metaevals and stack manipulation.

scryglass.book_description: The Scryglass Book, all in one place.
scryglass.name: Scryglass
scryglass.description: A Hexcasting addon to draw things on your screen!

slate_work.book_description: The Slate Work Book, all in one place.
slate_work.name: Slate Works
slate_work.description: An addon for improving and adding to Spell Circles in many different ways.

efhexs.book_description: The Special Efhexs Book, all in one place.
efhexs.name: Special Efhexs
efhexs.description: An addon dedicated to special effects via particles and sounds.

mediatransport.book_description: The Hex Casting + Figura Server Backend Addon
mediatransport.name: mediatransport

operators.description: Summons an enchanted version of the Greater Sentinel at the given position (which must be within 32 blocks around me) and the given ambit (which can be from 1-64). Costs 5 amethyst dust to summon.

Takes the location of a block with limited functionality and a full Simple Mind Container, and imbues the mind into the construct for five charged amethyst. [*This shape reminds me of something..*](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/great_spells/brainsweep)
Takes a block position and a positive number, and ages the block (or how I call it, induces a random tick) there that many times. Costs an amethyst shard per age-up.
Adds me, the caster, to the stack.
Transforms an entity on the stack into the position of its eyes. I should probably use this on myself.
Transforms an entity on the stack into the position it is standing. I should probably use this on other entities.
Transforms an entity on the stack into the direction it's looking in, as a unit vector.
Transforms an entity on the stack into its height.
Transforms an entity on the stack into the direction in which it's moving, with the speed of that movement as that direction's magnitude.

Combines two vectors (a position and a direction) into the answer to the question: If I stood at the position and looked in the direction, what block would I be looking at? Costs a negligible amount of media.

Like [Archer's Distillation](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/basics@hexcasting:raycast), but instead returns a vector representing the answer to the question: Which *side* of the block am I looking at? Costs a negligible amount of media.

Like [Archer's Distillation](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/basics@hexcasting:raycast), but instead returns the *entity* I am looking at. Costs a negligible amount of media.
Returns the position of the [Impetus](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#greatwork/impetus) of this spell circle.
Returns the direction the [Impetus](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#greatwork/impetus) of this spell circle is facing as a unit vector.
Returns the position of the lower-north-west corner of the bounds of this spell circle.
Returns the position of the upper-south-east corner of the bounds of this spell circle.
Swaps the top two iotas of the stack.
Yanks the iota third from the top of the stack to the top. [0, 1, 2] becomes [1, 2, 0].
Yanks the top iota to the third position. [0, 1, 2] becomes [2, 0, 1].
Duplicates the top iota of the stack.
Copy the second-to-last iota of the stack to the top. [0, 1] becomes [0, 1, 0].
Copy the top iota of the stack, then put it under the second iota. [0, 1] becomes [1, 0, 1].
Copy the top two iotas of the stack. [0, 1] becomes [0, 1, 0, 1].
Pushes the size of the stack as a number to the top of the stack. (For example, a stack of [0, 1] will become [0, 1, 2].)
Removes the number at the top of the stack, then copies the top iota of the stack that number of times. (A count of 2 results in two of the iota on the stack, not three.)
Grabs the element in the stack indexed by the number and brings it to the top. If the number is negative, instead moves the top element of the stack down that many elements.
Like [Fisherman's Gambit](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/stackmanip@hexcasting:fisherman), but instead of moving the iota, copies it.
Rearranges the top elements of the stack based on the given numerical code, which is the index of the permutation wanted.
Remove the list at the top of the stack, then add all its elements to the end of the list at the top of the stack.
Perform addition.
Performs Addition, num will be treated as num + 0i.
Remove the Jump iota at the top of the stack, then add all its frames to the bottom of the Jump iota at the top of the stack.
Perform Addition
Merges two maps together. Maps cannot have duplicate items: any entry in the latter map will override that in the first map.
Adds two matrices together; they must have the same number of columns and rows.

Combines two motes into one, merging the mote records they point to. Any pointers to the second mote will become null, any pointers to the first will remain. This can make motes holding many more items than I could carry in a stack naturally!
Performs Addition
Removes the top two strings from the stack and combines them together.
Pushes a [text iota](https://miyucomics.github.io/hexpose/v/1.0.0/1.0.0/en_us#patterns/text_iotas) of the first followed immediately by the second.
Perform subtraction.
Performs Subtraction, num will be treated as num + 0i.
Perform Subtraction
Removes every entry in the first map that is found in the second map. The values in the second map are ignored.
Performs Subtraction
Perform multiplication or the dot product.
Performs Multiplication
Perform Multiplication
Multiplies the first n by m by with an m by p matrix to get an n by p matrix.
Performs Multiplication, Scalar if a num & quat are given, Hamiltonian if 2 quaternions are given.
Perform division or the cross product.
Performs Scalar Division.
Perform Floored Division
Divides the first n by m matrix with an m by m matrix to get an n by m matrix.
Performs Scalar Division.
Convert a boolean to a number; True becomes 1, and False becomes 0.
Remove the list at the top of the stack, then push the number of elements in the list to the stack.
Compute the absolute value or length.
Pushes the Argument (the length).
Consumes a gate iota, returns how many entities are marked by that gate.
Transforms the Item Stack at the top of the stack into its size.
Remove the Jump iota at the top of the stack, then push the number of frames within it to the stack.
Accepts a mote and returns the number of items in the record referenced by that mote.
Pushes the Argument (the length).
Removes a string and returns its length.
Pushes the length of the [text iota](https://miyucomics.github.io/hexpose/v/1.0.0/1.0.0/en_us#patterns/text_iotas).
Perform exponentiation or vector projection.
Accepts a square matrix and an integer, and raises the matrix to the power of the integer.
Performs Exponentiation.
"Floors" a number, cutting off the fractional component and leaving an integer value. If passed a vector, instead floors each of its components.
"Ceilings" a number, raising it to the next integer value if it has a fractional component. If passed a vector, instead ceils each of its components.
Combine three numbers at the top of the stack into a vector's X, Y, and Z components (bottom to top).
Split a vector into its X, Y, and Z components (bottom to top).
For a vector, coerce it to its nearest axial direction, a unit vector. For a number, return the sign of the number; 1 if positive, -1 if negative. In both cases, zero is unaffected.
Takes the intersection of two sets.
Returns True if both arguments are true; otherwise returns False.
Perform Bitwise AND
Unifies two sets.
Returns True if at least one of the arguments are True; otherwise returns False.
Perform Bitwise OR
Takes the exclusive disjunction of two sets.
Returns True if exactly one of the arguments is true; otherwise returns False.
Perform Bitwise XOR
If the first argument is greater than the second, return True. Otherwise, return False.
If the first argument is less than the second, return True. Otherwise, return False.
If the first argument is greater than or equal to the second, return True. Otherwise, return False.
If the first argument is less than or equal to the second, return True. Otherwise, return False.
If the first argument equals the second (within a small tolerance), return True. Otherwise, return False.
If the first argument does not equal the second (outside a small tolerance), return True. Otherwise, return False.
If the argument is True, return False; if it is False, return True.

Takes the inversion of a bitset, changing all "on" bits to "off" and vice versa. In my experience, this will take the form of that number negated and decreased by one. For example, 0 will become -1, and -100 will become 99.
Perform Bitwise NOT
Convert an argument to a boolean. The number 0, [Null](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#casting/influences), False, and the empty list become False; everything else becomes True.
If the first argument is True, keeps the second and discards the third; otherwise discards the second and keeps the third.
Creates a random number between 0 and 1.

Takes the sine of an angle in radians, yielding the vertical component of that angle drawn on a unit circle. Related to the values of [π](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/consts@hexcasting:const/double/pi) and [τ](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/consts@hexcasting:const/double/tau).

Takes the cosine of an angle in radians, yielding the horizontal component of that angle drawn on a unit circle. Related to the values of [π](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/consts@hexcasting:const/double/pi) and [τ](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/consts@hexcasting:const/double/tau).

Takes the tangent of an angle in radians, yielding the slope of that angle drawn on a circle. Related to the values of [π](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/consts@hexcasting:const/double/pi) and [τ](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/consts@hexcasting:const/double/tau).

Takes the inverse sine of a value with absolute value 1 or less, yielding the angle whose sine is that value. Related to the values of [π](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/consts@hexcasting:const/double/pi) and [τ](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/consts@hexcasting:const/double/tau).

Takes the inverse cosine of a value with absolute value 1 or less, yielding the angle whose cosine is that value. Related to the values of [π](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/consts@hexcasting:const/double/pi) and [τ](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/consts@hexcasting:const/double/tau).

Takes the inverse tangent of a value, yielding the angle whose tangent is that value. Related to the values of [π](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/consts@hexcasting:const/double/pi) and [τ](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/consts@hexcasting:const/double/tau).
Takes the inverse tangent of a Y and X value, yielding the angle between the X-axis and a line from the origin to that point.

Removes the number at the top of the stack, then takes the logarithm of the number at the top using the other number as its base. Related to the value of [*e*](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/consts@hexcasting:const/double/e).
Takes the modulus of two numbers. This is the amount *remaining* after division - for example, 5 % 2 is 1, and 5 % 3 is 2. When applied on vectors, performs the above operation elementwise.
Removes duplicate entries from a list.
Keeps only the first instance of any glyph in the text. Styling is enough to distinguish a glyph.
Displays the top iota of the stack to me.
Remove a number and vector from the stack, then create an explosion at the given location with the given power.
Remove a number and vector from the stack, then create a fiery explosion at the given location with the given power.

Remove an entity and direction from the stack, then give a shove to the given entity in the given direction. The strength of the impulse is determined by the length of the vector.
Costs units of [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst) equal to the square of the length of the vector, plus one for every Impulse except the first targeting an entity.

Remove an entity and length from the stack, then teleport the given entity along its look vector by the given length.
Costs about one [Amethyst Shard](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst) per two blocks travelled.

Remove a location from the stack, then break the block at the given location. This spell can break nearly anything a Diamond Pickaxe can break.
Costs about an eighth of one [Amethyst Dust, or a negligible amount if breaking a ](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst)[](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/spells/blockworks@hexcasting:conjure_block)[Conjured Block](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/spells/blockworks@hexcasting:conjure_block) or [Conjured Light](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/spells/blockworks@hexcasting:conjure_light).

Remove a location from the stack, then pick a block item and place it at the given location.
Costs about an eighth of one [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).

I must be holding a [Pigment](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/pigments) in my other hand to cast this spell. When I do, it will consume the dye and permanently change my mind's coloration (at least, until I cast the spell again). Costs about one [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).

Certain items I create seem oddly receptive to the influence of media. By holding a [Cypher](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/hexcasting), [Trinket](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/hexcasting), [Artifact](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/hexcasting), [Focus](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/focus), or [Spellbook](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/spellbook) in my other hand, I can use this spell to change the appearance of the item. Costs about one [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).
Summon a block of water (or insert up to a bucket's worth) into a block at the given position. Costs about one [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).
Drains either a liquid container at, or a body of liquid around, the given position. Costs about two [Charged Amethyst](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).

Start a fire on top of the given location, as if a Fire Charge was applied, or sets fire to a creature. Costs about one [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).
Extinguish blocks in a large area. Costs about six [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).
Conjure an ethereal, but solid, block that sparkles with my pigment at the given position. Costs about one [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).
Conjure a magical light that softly glows with my pigment at the given position. Costs about one [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).
Encourage a plant or sapling at the target position to grow, as if Bonemeal was applied. Costs a bit more than one [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).
Recharge a media-containing item in my other hand. Costs about one [Amethyst Shard](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).
Clear a Hex-containing item in my other hand. Costs about one [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).

Forcibly infuse media into the sapling at the target position, causing it to grow into an [Edified Tree](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/edified). Costs about one [Charged Amethyst](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).
Remove a vector and two numbers from the stack. Plays an instrument defined by the first number at the given location, with a note defined by the second number. Costs a negligible amount of media.
Costs about one [Charged Amethyst](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).
Costs about five [Charged Amethysts](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).
Costs about ten [Charged Amethysts](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).
Infuse a bottle with media to form a [Phial.](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/phials)
Inflicts weakness. Base cost is one [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst) per 10 seconds.
Inflicts levitation. Base cost is one [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst) per 5 seconds.
Inflicts withering. Base cost is one [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst) per second.
Inflicts poison. Base cost is one [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst) per 3 seconds.
Inflicts slowness. Base cost is one [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst) per 5 seconds.
Bestows regeneration. Base cost is one [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst) per second.
Bestows night vision. Base cost is one [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst) per 5 seconds.
Bestows absorption. Base cost is one [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst) per second.
Bestows haste. Base cost is one [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst) per 3 seconds.
Bestows strength. Base cost is one [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst) per 3 seconds.
A flight limited in its range.
A flight limited in its duration.

Returns whether the given player is under the effects of [Anchorite's](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/spells/flight@hexcasting:flight/range) or [Wayfarer's Flight](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/spells/flight@hexcasting:flight/time).

Summons my [sentinel](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/spells/sentinels) at the given position. Costs about one [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).
Banish my [sentinel](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/spells/sentinels), and remove it from the world. Costs a negligible amount of media.

Add the position of my [sentinel](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/spells/sentinels) to the stack, or [Null](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#casting/influences) if it isn't summoned. Costs a negligible amount of media.

Transform the position vector on the top of the stack into a unit vector pointing from that position to my [sentinel](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/spells/sentinels), or [Null](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#casting/influences) if it isn't summoned. Costs a negligible amount of media.

I command the heavens! This spell will summon a bolt of lightning to strike the earth where I direct it. Costs about three [Amethyst Shards](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).
Summon a sheaf of media about me in the shape of wings, endowed with enough substance to allow gliding.
Summon a block of lava (or insert up to a bucket's worth) into a block at the given position. Costs about one [Charged Amethyst](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).

Far more powerful than [Blink](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/spells/basic@hexcasting:blink), this spell lets me teleport nearly anywhere in the entire world! There does seem to be a limit, but it is *much* greater than the normal radius of influence I am used to.

Summon a greater version of my [Sentinel](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/spells/sentinels). Costs about two [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).

A counterpart to summoning rain. This spell will dispel rain across the world I cast it upon. Costs about one [Amethyst Shard](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst). Does nothing if the skies are already clear.

I control the clouds! This spell will summon rain across the world I cast it upon. Costs about one [Charged Amethyst](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst). Does nothing if it is already raining.
I cannot make heads or tails of this spell... To be honest, I'm not sure I want to know what it does.

Read the iota associated with the given pattern out of the [Akashic Library](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#greatwork/akashiclib) with its [Record](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#greatwork/akashiclib) at the given position. This has no range limit. Costs about one [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).

Associate the iota with the given pattern in the [Akashic Library](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#greatwork/akashiclib) with its [Record](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#greatwork/akashiclib) at the given position. This *does* have a range limit. Costs about one [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).

Remove a pattern or list of patterns from the stack, then cast them as if I had drawn them myself with my [Staff](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/staff) (until a [Charon's Gambit](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/meta@hexcasting:halt) is encountered). If an iota is escaped with [Consideration](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/patterns_as_iotas@hexcasting:escape) or [its ilk](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/patterns_as_iotas@hexcasting:open_paren), it will be pushed to the stack. Otherwise, non-patterns will fail.

Cast a pattern or list of patterns from the stack exactly like [Hermes' Gambit](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/meta@hexcasting:eval), except that a unique "Jump" iota is pushed to the stack beforehand.
This pattern forcibly halts a Hex. This is mostly useless on its own, as I could simply just stop writing patterns, or put down my staff.
Copy the iota stored in the item in my other hand and add it to the stack.
Like [Scribe's Reflection](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/readwrite@hexcasting:read), but the iota is read out of an entity instead of my other hand.
Like [Scribe's Reflection](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/readwrite@hexcasting:read), but the iota is read out of a block instead of my other hand.
Remove the top iota from the stack, and save it into the item in my other hand.

Like [Scribe's Gambit](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/readwrite@hexcasting:read), but the iota is written to an entity instead of my other hand.
Interestingly enough, it looks like I cannot write my own Name using this spell. I get a sense that I might be endangered if I could.

Like [Scribe's Gambit](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/readwrite@hexcasting:write), but the iota is written to a block instead of my other hand.
Interestingly enough, it looks like I cannot write my own Name using this spell. I get a sense that I might be endangered if I could.
If the item in my other hand holds an iota I can read, returns True. Otherwise, returns False.
Like [Auditor's Reflection](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/readwrite@hexcasting:readable), but the readability of an entity is checked instead of my other hand.
Like [Auditor's Reflection](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/readwrite@hexcasting:readable), but the readability of a block is checked instead of my other hand.
If I could save an iota into the item in my other hand, returns True. Otherwise, returns False.
Like [Assessor's Reflection](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/readwrite@hexcasting:writable), but the writability of an entity is checked instead of my other hand.
Like [Assessor's Reflection](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/readwrite@hexcasting:writable), but the writability of a block is checked instead of my other hand.

Copy the iota out of my [ravenmind](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/readwrite@hexcasting:local), which I likely just wrote with [Huginn's Gambit](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/readwrite@hexcasting:write/local).

Removes the top iota from the stack, and saves it to my [ravenmind](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/readwrite@hexcasting:local), storing it there until I stop casting the Hex.
Adds the number of patterns a Hex is still capable of evaluating to the stack. This is reduced by one for each pattern cast by the Hex.
Adds the [Null](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#casting/influences) influence to the top of the stack.
Adds True to the top of the stack.
Adds False to the top of the stack.
The left-hand counter-clockwise pattern adds [1, 0, 0] to the stack; the right-hand clockwise pattern adds [-1, 0, 0].
The left-hand counter-clockwise pattern adds [0, 1, 0] to the stack; the right-hand clockwise pattern adds [0, -1, 0].
The left-hand counter-clockwise pattern adds [0, 0, 1]; the right-hand clockwise pattern adds [0, 0, -1].
The left-hand counter-clockwise pattern adds [1, 0, 0] to the stack; the right-hand clockwise pattern adds [-1, 0, 0].
The left-hand counter-clockwise pattern adds [0, 1, 0] to the stack; the right-hand clockwise pattern adds [0, -1, 0].
The left-hand counter-clockwise pattern adds [0, 0, 1]; the right-hand clockwise pattern adds [0, 0, -1].
Adds [0, 0, 0] to the stack.
Adds π, the radial representation of half a circle, to the stack.
Adds τ, the radial representation of a complete circle, to the stack.
Adds *e*, the base of natural logarithms, to the stack.
Transform the position on the stack into the entity at that location (or [Null](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#casting/influences) if there isn't one).
Transform the position on the stack into the animal at that location (or [Null](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#casting/influences) if there isn't one).
Transform the position on the stack into the monster at that location (or [Null](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#casting/influences) if there isn't one).
Transform the position on the stack into the dropped item at that location (or [Null](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#casting/influences) if there isn't one).
Transform the position on the stack into the player at that location (or [Null](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#casting/influences) if there isn't one).
Transform the position on the stack into the living creature at that location (or [Null](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#casting/influences) if there isn't one).
Take a position and maximum distance on the stack, and combine them into a list of all entities near the position.
Take a position and maximum distance on the stack, and combine them into a list of animals near the position.
Take a position and maximum distance on the stack, and combine them into a list of non-animal entities near the position.
Take a position and maximum distance on the stack, and combine them into a list of monsters near the position.
Take a position and maximum distance on the stack, and combine them into a list of non-monster entities near the position.
Take a position and maximum distance on the stack, and combine them into a list of dropped items near the position.
Take a position and maximum distance on the stack, and combine them into a list of non-dropped-item entities near the position.
Take a position and maximum distance on the stack, and combine them into a list of players near the position.
Take a position and maximum distance on the stack, and combine them into a list of non-player characters near the position.
Take a position and maximum distance on the stack, and combine them into a list of living creatures near the position.
Take a position and maximum distance on the stack, and combine them into a list of non-living entities near the position.
Remove the top of the stack, then add it to the end of the list at the top of the stack.
Remove the iota on the end of the list at the top of the stack, and add it to the top of the stack.
Shaves off one element of a map. Which element gets shaved off is undefined and subject to Nature's whims. If used on an empty map, returns two nulls.

Remove the number at the top of the stack, then replace the list at the top with the nth element of that list (where n is the number you removed). Replaces the list with [Null](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#casting/influences) if the number is out of bounds.
Disintegrates the map, returning only the value associated with the given key. O(1), unlike scanning a list.
Pushes the nth glyph in the text.
Remove a list of patterns and a list from the stack, then cast the given pattern over each element of the second list.
Remove the top of the stack, then push a list containing only that element.
Push an empty list to the top of the stack.
Reverse the list at the top of the stack.
Accepts an n by m matrix and returns an m by n matrix where every entry has been flipped along the diagonal.
Reverses the text.
Remove *num* elements from the stack, then add them to a list at the top of the stack.
Remove the list at the top of the stack, then push its contents to the stack.
Remove the Jump iota at the top of the stack, then, for each of its frames, push a new Jump iota containing only that frame to the stack.

Remove the iota at the top of the stack, then replace the list at the top with the first index of that iota within the list (starting from 0). Replaces the list with -1 if the iota doesn't exist in the list.
Removes two strings from the top of the stack, and returns the first index of the first string where the second string is a substring.
Remove the number at the top of the stack, then remove the nth element of the list at the top of the stack (where n is the number you removed).
Throws out the map's association for the given key. If there is no matching association, the map is returned unchanged.
Removes the nth glyph in the text.

Remove the two numbers at the top of the stack, then take a sublist of the list at the top of the stack between those indices, lower bound inclusive, upper bound exclusive. For example, the 0, 2 sublist of [0, 1, 2, 3, 4] would be [0, 1].
Removes a string and two positive integers from the top of the stack, and returns the substring from the first to the second (inclusive first, exclusive second).
Pushes the specified slice of the text.

Remove the top iota of the stack and the number at the top, then set the nth element of the list at the top of the stack to that iota (where n is the number you removed). Does nothing if the number is out of bounds.
Replaces the element associated with __k__ with __v__. If __k__ is not present in the map, the entry is created.
Replaces the glyph at the nth position in the text with another segment of text. Replacement can be longer than one glyph.
Remove the top iota, then add it as the first element to the list at the top of the stack.
Remove the Jump iota at the top of the stack, then add its top frame to the top of the Jump iota at the top of the stack.
Remove the first iota from the list at the top of the stack, then push that iota to the stack.
Remove the top frame from the Jump iota at the top of the stack, then push a new Jump iota containing only that frame to the stack.
Get the scale of the entity, as a proportion of their normal size. For most entities, this will be 1.
Set the scale of the entity, passing in a proportion of their normal size. Costs about 1 Amethyst Shard.

Cast a pattern or list of patterns from the stack exactly like [Hermes' Gambit](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/meta@hexcasting:eval), except that anything outside of this cast will not be captured by an [Arke's Gambit](https://caduceus.hexxy.media/v/0.1.1+1.20.1/1.0/en_us#patterns/delimcc@caduceus:eval/control) within it.

Cast a pattern or list of patterns from the stack similarly to [Iris' Gambit](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/meta@hexcasting:eval/cc). Must be drawn within [Thetis' Gambit](https://caduceus.hexxy.media/v/0.1.1+1.20.1/1.0/en_us#patterns/delimcc@caduceus:eval/prompt).

Like [Ewer's Reflection](https://caduceus.hexxy.media/v/0.1.1+1.20.1/1.0/en_us#patterns/jump_manipulation@caduceus:read/mark/local), but the iota is read out of the jump tag of the top frame in a Jump iota.
Copy the iota stored in the jump tag of the current evaluation and add it to the stack.

Remove the top iota from the stack, and write it to the jump tag of the current evaluation.
As with [Chronicler's Gambit](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/readwrite@hexcasting:write/entity), I cannot write my own Name using this spell.
Pushes 1 + 0i to the stack.
Pushes 0 + 1i to the stack.
Pushes the real coefficient.
Pushes the imaginary coefficient.
Negates the imaginary coefficient of the topmost iota
Pushes 1 + 0i + 0j + 0k to the stack.
Pushes 0 + 1i + 0j + 0k to the stack.
Pushes 0 + 0i + 1j + 0k to the stack.
Pushes 0 + 0i + 0j + 1k to the stack.
Negates the coefficients of i, j, & k
Pushes the coefficient of 1.
Pushes the coefficient of i.
Pushes the coefficient of j.
Pushes the coefficient of k.
Pushes a Quaternion with num as the real coefficient and the vector's x, y, & z as the coefficients of i, j & k respectively.
Pushes the real coefficient and a vector where the x, y, & z components are the coefficients of i, j, & k respectively.
Pushes a matrix that (should) represent the same rotation as the quaternion
Pushes a quaternion that (should) reperesent the same rotation as the matrix
Pushes a quaternion that reperesents a rotation by the given angle num radias around the given vector.

Summons a Block Display entity at the given position, displaying the given block. (The string must be the internal name i.e "minecraft:dirt", not "Dirt").
Costs about a [Charged Amethyst](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst)

Summons an Item Display entity at the given position, displaying the given item (The string must be the internal name i.e "minecraft:stick", not "Stick").
Costs about a [Charged Amethyst](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst)
Summons a Text Display entity at the given position, displaying the given string. Costs about a [Charged Amethyst](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst)
Kills & removes the given BIT.
Translates the BIT to the given offset.
Rotates the BIT to the given Quaternion.
Scales the BIT to the given vector.
Pushes a 4x4 matrix representing the Bit's Transformation.
Sets the Transformation of a BIT to the given 4x4 matrix.
Transform the position on the stack into the BIT at that location (or [Null](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#casting/influences) if there isn't one)
Take a position and a maximum distance on the stack, and combine them into a list of BIT's near the position.
Take a position and a maximum distance on the stack, and combine them into a list of non-BIT's near the position.
Pushes a Bubbled Iota, which when popped via execution (by Hermes' or the likes), will push the contained iota to the stack.

Swaps between a string of a *single character* and an integer representing that character.
Uses the UTF-16 character map.

Converts between [doubles](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/numbers) and longs
Always truncates the value when converting to long
Shifts all the bits to the left num times
Shifts all the bits to the right num times
Shifts all the bits to the right num times while preserving the sign
Creates a new symbol with the given (single character) label
Substitutes the third expression/number in place of the second expression within the first.
Creates an expression that equals 1 if the two expressions are equal, and 0 otherwise.
Creates a piecewise expression that simplifies to the second argument if the first simplifies to 1.0, otherwise simplifies to the third argument.
Takes in an expression and a lone symbol and returns the partial derivative of the expression with respect to the symbol.
Takes in a width, height and expression and creates a matrix by substituting i & j-values into the expression corresponding to a position in the matrix and putting the result in the matrix.
Summons a parametric line at the given position. The expression given will have a t-value (0-1), x/y/z position, and time (w) substituted in and must resolve to a vector on the line.
Summons a parametric surface at the given position. The expression given will have a u&v-value (0-1), x/y/z position, and time (w) substituted in and must resolve to a vector on the surface
Evaluates the hyperbolic sine of the argument
Evaluates the hyperbolic sine of the argument
Evaluates the hyperbolic sine of the argument
Evaluates the hyperbolic sine of the argument
Evaluates the hyperbolic sine of the argument
Evaluates the hyperbolic sine of the argument
Provided a tree's position, I can extract the Species of the tree.
Provided a tree's position, I can extract the structure of the tree as a Base64 string.

Provided a tree's position, I can command Nature to change the very Species of the tree till my heart's content, provided I have the media equivalent of a Shard per character in the string which defines its' structure.
Functions just like the normal [Zeniths](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/great_spells/zeniths), applying Invisibility. Costs one amethyst dust per three seconds.

Accepts a player to grant the armor to, the durability of the armor, the protection value of the armor (max 10), a status effect to apply, and that effect's level. The latter two can be replaced with any non-status iota to ignore them.
Accepts a raw media item on the ground, and attempts to use it to repair a tool in my other hand.
Accepts an entity and a status effect type, and removes that status effect from the entity. Cost is based on the effect's innate harmfulness, its potency, and its remaining duration.
Accepts a living entity, and returns a list of status iotas representing all effects on the target.
Accepts a status effect type, and returns a number based on whether the effect is likely to be helpful, harmful, or neutral to a creature.
Accepts an entity and a status effect type, and returns the effect on the target's duration in seconds.
Accepts an entity and a status effect type, and returns the effect on the target's potency.
Accepts a status effect type, a vector, and a number (*n*), and returns a list of entities within radius *n* of the vector which have that effect.
Accepts a status effect type, a vector, and a number (*n*), and returns a list of entities within radius *n* of the vector which do not have that effect.
Accepts a status effect type and a vector, and returns an entity at that position which has that effect.
Accepts a living entity, and returns how much damage it can Absorb before its health is affected.

As [Scout's Distillation](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/basics@hexcasting:raycast/entity), but also accepts a list of entity type iotas. Any entity whose type is not present in the list will be ignored. Costs an amount of media slightly less negligible than that of the aforementioned pattern.
Returns a random number with a gaussian distribution, with a mean of zero and a standard deviation of one.
Accepts any iota, and converts it into its hashed form.
Accepts a player and returns how much amethyst dust it would cost to send them a message via Postman's Gambit, between 1/10 of a dust and 10 dust.
Returns how many times the item in my other hand can be used without breaking, durability-manipulating effects notwithstanding.
As previous, targeting the item in the hand I'm casting this with. Most useful with delayed casts of one form or another.
Accepts any iota, and returns its total size.
Returns the total size of all iotas on my stack, including the contents of lists and similar. If this number ever reaches 1024, my stack shall come crashing down into garbage.
Accepts a vector, and returns whether that vector is within (or just on the edge of) the block in that space. Seems to involve the boxes I see in my mind's eye.
Pops an iota from the accumulator and pushes it to the current stack. Mishaps if used outside of Thoth's Gambit.
Returns how many iotas are currently accessible via Seshat's Gambit. Returns -1 if used outside of Thoth's Gambit.
Accepts a vector, and returns a list of strings corresponding to values contained in the state of the block at the corresponding position.
Accepts a vector and a string, and uses the string as a key to retrieve the value it corresponds to in the target block's state, or null if there is no corresponding value.
Accepts an entity, and returns a list of entities seated atop it.
Accepts an entity, and returns the entity it is seated atop.
Returns true if the target is under the effects of Anchorite's Flight, false if Wayfarer's Flight, null if neither.
Returns how close the target is to the end of their flight spell, represented as either their distance to the boundary or how many seconds remain.
Accepts an item frame entity, and returns its rotation, from 0 to 7.
Accepts an item frame entity and an integer from 0 to 7, and sets its rotation to the number. Costs a negligible amount of media.
Scans the link network connected to the input linkable up to a recursion depth equal to the input number (max 32), and returns a list of all connected linkables. Costs a negligible amount of media.

Accepts a linkable to use for network access, and any iota. If a relay connected to the network has an adjacent Network Routing Index with the same iota, returns that relay's position. Costs half an amethyst dust.

Accepts an entity to teleport, a linkable to use for access to its network, and a destination. If the entity is within 8 blocks of the linkable, and there is a network node within 4 blocks of the destination, the entity will be teleported. Cost varies based on what entity is teleported.
Accepts two vectors and two numbers, and uses them to define a burst of particles. Costs a negligible amount of media.
Accepts a vector and an itemtype representing a pigment. Costs a negligible amount of media if targeting my own block, or 1 Amethyst Dust if not.

Accepts a player and any iota less than 256 characters long, and shows that iota to them as if they had cast Reveal, also telling them who sent the message. Cost is inversely proportional to the length of time since they were last targeted by this spell.
Resets the cost of sending me a message via Postman's Gambit back to 1/10 of a dust. Costs 1/10 of a dust.

Accepts one of my wisps (or a wandering wisp), and places me atop it, similar to sitting in a minecart. I must be within the wisp's ambit, or four blocks for wandering wisps. Costs one amethyst shard.
Takes me off of whatever entity I may be riding when cast. Costs 1/100 of a dust.
Cancels my current flight ability, at a cost of one tenth of an Amethyst Dust. Casting a new flight spell in the same instant allows me to continue flying, potentially with different parameters.

Cast the given spell from myself.
Costs 1 dust for each glyph used.

Cast the given spell from the given TrueName.
Costs 1 charged crystal for each glyph used.

Cast the given spell as a projectile shooting from certain position & angle. One Glyph of Projectile will be inserted before the given glyphs.
Costs 1 shard plus 1 dust for each glyph used.

Cast the given spell on given entity or position. One Glyph of Touch will be inserted before the given glyphs.
Costs 1 shard plus 1 dust for each glyph used.

Read all glyphs from a given entity: could be an item like glyph, spellcaster and parchment, or item frames containing those, or a player with learnt glyphs.
This could be the only way to obtain a glyph iota if I choose to deny the evil power of HexParse.
Register the given spell list as callback, which will be executed when "Trigger Callback" glyph executes.
Read the callback spell list registered.
Add a Cognitohazard to the top of the stack.

Add True to the top of the stack if executed by a [Debugger](https://hexdebug.hexxy.media/v/0.7.0+1.20.1/1.1/en_us#items/debugging@debugger) or [Evaluator](https://hexdebug.hexxy.media/v/0.7.0+1.20.1/1.1/en_us#items/debugging@evaluator), or False otherwise.

Add the index of the next iota to be evaluated if executed by a [Debugger](https://hexdebug.hexxy.media/v/0.7.0+1.20.1/1.1/en_us#items/debugging@debugger) or [Evaluator](https://hexdebug.hexxy.media/v/0.7.0+1.20.1/1.1/en_us#items/debugging@evaluator), or [Null](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#casting/influences) otherwise.
Pause the [Debugger](https://hexdebug.hexxy.media/v/0.7.0+1.20.1/1.1/en_us#items/debugging@debugger) before executing this pattern.
Pause the [Debugger](https://hexdebug.hexxy.media/v/0.7.0+1.20.1/1.1/en_us#items/debugging@debugger) after executing this pattern (ie. before executing the next pattern).

Create a [Debugger](https://hexdebug.hexxy.media/v/0.7.0+1.20.1/1.1/en_us#items/debugging@debugger) that casts a Hex, similar to [certain other patterns](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/spells/hexcasting) I've used in the past.
Costs about ten [Charged Amethyst](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).

Remove a vector from the stack, then push two values representing the current selection in the [Splicing Table](https://hexdebug.hexxy.media/v/0.7.0+1.20.1/1.1/en_us#items/splicing_table) at that position.

Remove a vector and two values from the stack, then set the selection of the [Splicing Table](https://hexdebug.hexxy.media/v/0.7.0+1.20.1/1.1/en_us#items/splicing_table) at that position as previously described.

Remove a vector from the stack, then push the index of the leftmost iota currently visible in the [Splicing Table](https://hexdebug.hexxy.media/v/0.7.0+1.20.1/1.1/en_us#items/splicing_table) at that position.

Remove a vector and number from the stack, then move the view of the [Splicing Table](https://hexdebug.hexxy.media/v/0.7.0+1.20.1/1.1/en_us#items/splicing_table) at that position so that the given index is the leftmost one visible.

Remove a vector from the stack, then push the current page number (starting at 1) of the [Spellbook](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/spellbook) in the main slot of the [Splicing Table](https://hexdebug.hexxy.media/v/0.7.0+1.20.1/1.1/en_us#items/splicing_table) or [Focal Frame](https://hexdebug.hexxy.media/v/0.7.0+1.20.1/1.1/en_us#items/focus_holder) at that position.

Remove a vector and number from the stack, then flip the [Spellbook](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/spellbook) in the main slot of the [Splicing Table](https://hexdebug.hexxy.media/v/0.7.0+1.20.1/1.1/en_us#items/splicing_table) or [Focal Frame](https://hexdebug.hexxy.media/v/0.7.0+1.20.1/1.1/en_us#items/focus_holder) at that position to the given page number.

Replace the vector at the top of the stack with True if there is a [Splicing Table](https://hexdebug.hexxy.media/v/0.7.0+1.20.1/1.1/en_us#items/splicing_table) or [Focal Frame](https://hexdebug.hexxy.media/v/0.7.0+1.20.1/1.1/en_us#items/focus_holder) at that position with a [Spellbook](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/spellbook) in its main slot that contains at least one page, or False otherwise.

Remove a vector from the stack, then copy the contents of the secondary item in the [Splicing Table](https://hexdebug.hexxy.media/v/0.7.0+1.20.1/1.1/en_us#items/splicing_table) at that position and push it to the stack.

Remove a vector and iota from the stack, then save the iota into the secondary item in the [Splicing Table](https://hexdebug.hexxy.media/v/0.7.0+1.20.1/1.1/en_us#items/splicing_table) at that position.
As with [Chronicler's Gambit](https://ioticblocks.hexxy.media/v/1.0.2+1.20.1/1.0/en_us#patterns/readwrite_blocks@hexcasting:write/entity), I cannot write my own Name using this spell.

Replace the vector at the top of the stack with True if there is a [Splicing Table](https://hexdebug.hexxy.media/v/0.7.0+1.20.1/1.1/en_us#items/splicing_table) at that position containing a secondary item that I could read, or False otherwise.

Replace the vector at the top of the stack with True if there is a [Splicing Table](https://hexdebug.hexxy.media/v/0.7.0+1.20.1/1.1/en_us#items/splicing_table) at that position containing a secondary item that I could save an iota into, or False otherwise.

Like [Projectionist's Purification](https://hexdebug.hexxy.media/v/0.7.0+1.20.1/1.1/en_us#patterns/splicing_table@hexdebug:splicing/list/spellbook_index/read), but the page number of the [Spellbook](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/spellbook) in the secondary slot is read instead of the main slot.

Like [Projectionist's Gambit](https://hexdebug.hexxy.media/v/0.7.0+1.20.1/1.1/en_us#patterns/splicing_table@hexdebug:splicing/list/spellbook_index/write), but the page number of the [Spellbook](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/spellbook) in the secondary slot is written instead of the main slot.

Like [Shutter's Purification](https://hexdebug.hexxy.media/v/0.7.0+1.20.1/1.1/en_us#patterns/splicing_table@hexdebug:splicing/list/spellbook_index/readable), but the [Spellbook](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/spellbook) in the secondary slot is checked instead of the main slot.

Remove a vector from the stack, then push the Hex currently imbued to the [Mindsplice Table](https://hexdebug.hexxy.media/v/0.7.0+1.20.1/1.1/en_us#greatwork/enlightened_splicing_table) at that position, or [Null](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#casting/influences) if it has not yet been imbued.

Remove a vector and list of patterns from the stack, then imbue the list of patterns into the [Mindsplice Table](https://hexdebug.hexxy.media/v/0.7.0+1.20.1/1.1/en_us#greatwork/enlightened_splicing_table) at that position.
Costs about five [Charged Amethyst](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).
Similar to [Thoth's Gambit](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/meta@hexcasting:for_each), but won't copy the original stack inside each sub-execution.

Similar to [Thoth's Gambit](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/meta@hexcasting:for_each); for data list with length **n**, it executes **n - 1** times; The first initial stack is the first two elements, and each subsequent execution uses the stack after the last execution.
Copy list #0 and set back to index #1
List iota #0 is the nested list to be modified. According to the index sequence given by list #1, traverses to the inner layer, and sets the corresponding element to iota #2.

Accepts the size to reorder and a bottom-to-top order list, and do the corresponding reorder to the rest of the stack. For example, **3** plus **[1,2,0]** for [Rotation Gambit](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/stackmanip@hexcasting:rotate), and **2** plus **[0,1,0,1]** for [Dioscuri Gambit](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/stackmanip@hexcasting:2dup)

Same as [Consideration](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/patterns_as_iotas@hexcasting:escape), but with lowest execution priority, and won't grow in **2^n** formula exponentially inside nested [Intro-Retro](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/patterns_as_iotas@hexcasting:open_paren)s

Transitions the caster to a female!
I wonder how I'd look in a skirt...

Transitions the caster to a male!
No more periods!

Transitions the caster to androgynous!
Hmm... this is... interesting...
Obtains the target's selected gender as an ordinal (number)
Gives the bust size of the target
Sets the bust size of the caster
Gives the bounciness of the target's breasts
Sets the bounciness of the caster's breasts
Gives the floppiness of the target's breasts
Sets the floppiness of the caster's breasts
Gives the physics of the target's breasts
Sets the physics of the caster's breasts
Gets the cleavage of the target's breasts
Sets the cleavage of the caster's breasts
Gets the offset of the target's breasts
Sets the offset of the caster's breasts
Gets whether the target's breasts are a uniboob
Sets whether the caster's breasts are a uniboob
Creates a new Circle Marker with the provided identifier, label, position, and radius
Creates a new Rectangle Marker with the provided identifier, label, top corner, and bottom corner
Creates a new Polygon Marker with the provided identifier, label, and list of positions OR a Hexical Mesh Entity
Creates a new Polyline Marker with the provided identifier, label, and list of positions OR a Hexical Mesh Entity
Creates a new Icon Marker with the provided identifier, label, icon, and position
Checks if a marker exists on the map under the provided identifier
Sets the Fill Color of a marker, if applicable (Circle, Rectangle, and Polygon)
Sets the Line Color of a marker, if applicable (Circle, Rectangle, Polyline, and Polygon)
Sets the Line Weight of a marker, if applicable (Circle, Rectangle, Polyline, and Polygon)

Adds the provided marker to the map under the provided identifier
Ambit validation is done here
Removed the marker on the map under the provided identifier
Pushes a list of Maps for your current dimension from Bluemap to the stack
Pushes a list of Maps for your current dimension from Dynmap to the stack
Pushes a list of Maps for your current dimension from Pl3xmap to the stack
Pushes a list of Maps for your current dimension from Squaremap to the stack
Charges the current casting environment to an equivalent of **114514** amethyst dust media.
Gets how much media exists in my personal media bar (in **0.0001** dust).
Gets how much media I could hold in my personal media bar at most (in **0.0001** dust).
Pops the top iota from current stack, and pushes into the staff casting stack.
Pops the top iota from the staff casting stack, and pushes into current stack.
Gets the size of the staff casting stack.
Gets the list of all pattern iotas in the current staff canvas, returned in the order they were drawn.

Reads code from my local clipboard, then parse it into the focus I'm holding.
Can only be casted by staff.

Reads data from the focus I'm holding, and prints parsed code into chat menu.
Can only be casted by staff.
Clears all comment iotas in a list, returns processed list.
Extract great patterns from handheld items (ancient scrolls, focuses, compiled casting items, etc.), and returns a list of newly learned ones by the parser.
Adds a line-break comment iota with space-indents of given number to the stack.
Compiles accepted string iota into an iota list; has no effect if **MoreIotas** not installed.

Removes the locations of two corners from the stack, then consumes a region of space defined by those two corners, storing the result in a Structure iota.
Costs about an eighth of one [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst) for every block consumed.

Removes the location of the structure's origin and a structure from the stack, then attempts to place the structure at the origin, erasing the structure from all memory. Mishaps if any part of the structure overlaps with another block.
Costs about an eighth of one [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst) for every block placed.
Flips a stored Structure left-to-right, or across the X-axis.
Flips a stored Structure front-to-back, or across the Z-axis.
Rotates a stored Structure 90-degrees clockwise.
Rotates a stored Structure 90-degrees counterclockwise.
Removes the location of the structure's origin and a structure from the stack, followed by a duration between 0 and 72000.

Removes a Structure from the stack, returning its transformations as a list in the format [mirror, rotation].
No Mirror -> 0; Front-Back -> 1; Left-Right -> 2
No Rotation -> 0; 90 CW -> 1; 180 CW -> 2; 90 CCW -> 3

Takes a pattern and makes it unique to me by injecting patterns that I cannot draw by hand
also seems to put more power into certain spells
Turns the spellbook that your are holding one page to the right
Turns the spellbook that your are holding one page to the left

Removes a pattern list from the stack. Examines (but does not remove) the iota beneath it, and evaluates the pattern list if and only if [Augur's Purification](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/logic@hexcasting:bool_coerce) would respond to that iota with True. Examination and evaluation repeats until the iota would no longer create truth.
Returns the posistion of the Wave of media passing through a [Spell Circle](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#greatwork/impetus)
Returns the normal of the slate the Wave is on in the [Spell Circle](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#greatwork/impetus)
Creates an empty JSON object.
Turns the given String into a JSON object. If it cannot be parsed into a JSON object itself, a wrapper JSON object will be created.
Sets the given iota at the given key. Setting a Garbage iota removes the key.
Gets the stored iota at the given key. Mishaps upon their being no iota.
Checks whether the given JSON iota has the given key.

Sends an HTTP request made of the given data, method, and headers to the provided URL.
The Response is truthy if a response is received.
Given a Response Iota, attempt to parse the results. Will Mishap if too early or an IOException is thrown.
Adds a number to the stack which seems to be related to how Nature represents time; If I cast the pattern, then cast the same pattern a second later, the number it adds has increased by 20.
Removes a Living entity from the stack and returns how much breath it has left (i.e., how close it is to drowning).
Removes a Living entity from the stack and returns how much health it has left (i.e., how close it is to dying).
Removes a Living entity from the stack and returns how much armour it has.
Removes a Living entity from the stack and returns how much toughness it has (another property of armour).
Removes a position vector from the stack and returns the light level at that position.
Takes a number from the stack and computes its factorial, for example inputting 4 would return 4\*3\*2\*1=24.
Takes a list from the stack and computes its running sum, for example inputting [1,2,5] would return [1,3,8].
Takes a list from the stack and computes its running product, for example inputting [1,2,5] would return [1,2,10].

Takes the position of an [Akashic Record](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#greatwork/akashiclib), as well as a Pattern as a key, and retrieves the iota at that key from your Everbook, storing it in the given [Akashic Record](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#greatwork/akashiclib) if able.

Takes the position of an [Akashic Record](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#greatwork/akashiclib), as well as a Pattern as a key, and stores the iota in that record at that key to your Everbook at the same key.
Takes a pattern and removes the entry with that pattern key from your Everbook.
Takes a pattern and marks that entry of your Everbook as a Pattern that when drawn by your hand will be treated as any other of Nature's patterns.
Remove a location, item entity, or mote from the stack, then either smelt the block at the location or smelt all the items in the item entity or mote.
Freezes the block at a block location. For example, turns water into ice, and ice into packed ice. Costs one [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).

Remove a location from the stack, and force the block there to fall as if it were sand or gravel. Costs one and a half [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).

Accepts an item type or mote and a location, and attempts to place a block of that item type at that location. If a mote was passed it will instead place from the record referenced by that mote. Costs an eighth of an [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).

Accepts a location or a list of locations, and either creates a particle at the location, or creates lines of particles between the locations in the list. Costs two thousandths of an [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst) per location.
This wisp is summoned and launched like an arrow, casting its hex on whatever it hits. The initial stack when it executes will be a reference to itself, then a reference to what it hit.
Similar to Summon Projectile Wisp, but with only one vector input for the position to summon the wisp. Cyclic wisps are unmoving once summoned, instead executing their hex up to 20 times each second.
Add a reference to the casting wisp to the stack. This must be cast by a wisp; trying to cast it through a staff will fail rather spectacularly.
Add the amount of media in the wisp's reservoir to the stack. This must be cast by a wisp; trying to cast it through a staff will fail rather spectacularly.

Removes a reference to a wisp from the stack, and replaces it with the wisp's contained hex. Must be a wisp you summoned, or a wisp that has [allowed](https://hexal.hexxy.media/v/0.3.0/1.0/en_us#patterns/spells/wisps@hexal:wisp/transfer/allow) transfer with the caster or caster's owner.
Removes a reference to a wisp and an entity from the stack, and returns true if that entity owns that wisp, and false otherwise.
Removes a position vector from the stack; The Cyclic Wisp that executed this pattern will move in a straight line towards that position (colliding with terrain in its path) until it reaches it.
Adds to the stack the position vector that the executing Cyclic Wisp is currently moving towards.
Removes a number from the stack, and sets the executing Cyclic Wisp's maximum speed to that number.
Gets the executing Cyclic Wisp's current maximum speed.

When two wisps are [linked](https://hexal.hexxy.media/v/0.3.0/1.0/en_us#patterns/spells/links) together, they transfer media between each other until they are balanced. By default this only happens between wisps with the same owner. This takes an index, and explicitly allows the wisp to exchange media with the linkable at that index.
Correspondingly, this takes an index and disallows the wisp from exchanging media with the linkable at that index.
This takes a wisp that you own and an index, and allows the wisp to exchange media with the linkable at that index.
This takes a wisp that you own and an index, and disallows the wisp from exchanging media with the linkable at that index.
Transform the position on the stack into the wisp at that location (or [Null](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#casting/influences) if there isn't one).
Take a position and maximum distance on the stack, and combine them into a list of wisps near the position.
Take a position and maximum distance on the stack, and combine them into a list of non-wisp entities near the position.

Removes an integer from the stack, then delays the wisp's next cast until at least that many twentieth's of a second have passed. This and other triggers like it will halve the wisp's upkeep cost while it isn't casting.
The wisp's next cast will not occur until it has received at least one [communication](https://hexal.hexxy.media/v/0.3.0/1.0/en_us#patterns/spells/links@hexal:link/comm/send).
The wisp's next cast will not occur until it has reached the position it is [navigating](https://hexal.hexxy.media/v/0.3.0/1.0/en_us#patterns/spells/wisps@hexal:wisp/move/target/set) towards.
Returns my currently bound wisp. A new wisp can only be bound when this returns null. (This is not a great spell, I have simply placed it here for convenience.)
Links the caster to the entity removed from the stack, which must be linkable. This costs one [Amethyst Shard](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).
May be evaluated by any casting instrument. Links two entities, which must be linkable. This costs one [Amethyst Shard](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).
Removes the link at the given index from the caster's links. This costs two [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).
Takes two linkables and unlinks them if they are linked. This costs two [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).
Removes an index from the stack, and adds the entity connected to the link at that index to the stack.
Removes an entity from the stack, and adds the index to the link to that entity to the stack (or -1 if the caster isn't linked to that entity).
Adds the number of links to the wisp to the stack.

Removes an iota from the stack, then removes an index from the stack and sends the iota along the link at the given index.  This costs one hundredth of an [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).
When something receives an iota along a link it is added to a queue. This pattern adds the first iota in the queue to the stack, removing it from the queue.
Adds to the stack the number of unread iota in the caster's received iota queue.
Removes all unread iota from the caster's received iota queue.

Similar to [Introspection](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/patterns_as_iotas@hexcasting:open_paren), until drawing a [Close Transmit](https://hexal.hexxy.media/v/0.3.0/1.0/en_us#patterns/spells/links@hexal:link/comm/close_transmit) all patterns I draw are sent along the link whose index is at the top of the stack.

When drawn after [Open Transmit](https://hexal.hexxy.media/v/0.3.0/1.0/en_us#patterns/spells/links@hexal:link/comm/open_transmit) I stop transmitting drawn patterns. If either [Open Transmit](https://hexal.hexxy.media/v/0.3.0/1.0/en_us#patterns/spells/links@hexal:link/comm/open_transmit) or [Close Transmit](https://hexal.hexxy.media/v/0.3.0/1.0/en_us#patterns/spells/links@hexal:link/comm/close_transmit) are executed by an intermediary caster such as a wisp, they will mishap.

Consumes a gate iota and an entity. Marks that entity to be teleported the next time that gate is closed. Costs one twentieth of an [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).

Consumes a gate iota and an entity. Unmarks that entity so that if it was marked with [ Gate's Opening](https://hexal.hexxy.media/v/0.3.0/1.0/en_us#patterns/great_spells/gates@hexal:gate/mark) it will no longer be teleported the next time that gate is closed.
Consumes a gate iota and an entity, returns whether that entity is marked by that gate.

Consumes a non-drifing gate iota, or a drifting gate iota and a position. Transports all the entities marked with the passed gate to the stored or given position, as relevant. Costs half an [Amethyst Shard](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst), plus an [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst) per metre transported per entity, if the gate was drifting.

Target a Mote Nexus block in the world and bind yourself to it, meaning all items you mediafy will be added to that nexus' capacity. Targeting any other block will unbind you from your currently bound nexus. Costs 32 [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).

Target a Mote Nexus block in the world and bind to it for the remainder of this cast, temporarily overriding your primary binding. Costs one thousandth of an [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).
Gets all the types of motes contained in the currently bound Mote Nexus.
Gets all the mote records from the currently bound Mote Nexus that match the passed item type or could be combined with the passed mote.
Gets the remaining capacity of the bound Mote Nexus.
Returns true if the Mote Nexus at the given position contains a mote of the given type, or that would stack with the given mote, and false otherwise.

Convert an item in the world (either an item entity or an item frame) into a mote on your stack. If passed an existing mote instead adds the items from the entity to the mote. Mediafying an item costs a tenth of an [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).

Returns all the items from a mote to the world at the location of your choosing. If passed a number returns at most that many items. Costs a tenth of an [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).
Returns true if the first mote can be combined with the items in the second argument (which can be a mote, item stack, item entity, or item frame), and false otherwise.
Splits the specified number of items off of the passed mote, creating a new mote pointing to a new mote record.
Get the position of the Mote Nexus that contains the passed mote.
Move the record referenced by the passed mote to the Mote Nexus at the passed position. This returns a new mote pointing to that record, and invalidates all previous motes pointing to that record.
Takes a mote, list of motes, or list of list of motes. returns a list containing the results of crafting with those items. For example, the input Stone x128 would return [Stone Button x128].

Takes the same input as [Craft](https://hexal.hexxy.media/v/0.3.0/1.0/en_us#patterns/spells/motes@hexal:mote/craft), except it can take Item Stack Iotas as well as motes. Returns a list of Item Stack Iotas representing what the results of [Craft](https://hexal.hexxy.media/v/0.3.0/1.0/en_us#patterns/spells/motes@hexal:mote/craft) would have been with motes containing those inputs.
Accepts a villager, returns a number representing that villager's seniority and skill at their craft.

Accepts a villager and returns all of the trades that villager is offering. This is a list of lists of lists. Each trade comprises two lists, the cost, and the returned items. The returned items is a list containing the type of item, and the number of items.

Accepts a villager, a list of motes to trade with to villager, and optionally an int for which of that villager's trades to attempt. (int? above means that you can pass 2 or 3 arguments, the optional 3rd being an int).

Accepts a mote, and either an entity, or a target block and a normal vector. Uses the item on the entity/block. The mote must either only have one item in it, or the items contained must be extremely simple (no NBT data).
Remove a wisp from the stack, and disassemble the wisp. The patterns contained are lost, but the media that it contained can be repurposed if this spell is cast by another wisp.
Bind one of my wisps closer to me; I may only have one bound wisp at a time, but whichever wisp is bound costs significantly less upkeep and increased range.
Causes the block at the passed vector to perform its normal actions faster in the instant that this spell is cast.

Adds a new gate iota to the stack. Any copy of this iota will point to the same numbered gate. Costs 32 [Charged Amethyst](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst). If passed null, makes a Drifting Gate. If passed a vector, makes a Location Anchored Gate, If passed a vector and an entity, makes an Entity Anchored Gate.

Takes a position and a number, and phases the block at that position out for that many seconds. Costs one ten-thousandth of an [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst) times the square of the time to phase out for.
Enqueues a Hex to cast after that many twentieths of a second. It takes an iota to use as the label for the cassette.
I can also automate killing cassettes with this pattern. It takes an iota and dequeues the cassette with that label if it exists.
Terminates all cassettes, similar to the effects of the Parallel Processing mishap.
Pushes the total number of cassettes slots that I currently have.
