Pushes the number of non-busy cassette slots that I currently have.
Pushes null if I do not have an active cassette with that label, or the cassette's Hex if I do. I hear rumors of this being used for iota storage and passing information between Hexes.
Pushes null if I do not have an active cassette with that label, or how many twentieths of a second until that cassette fires if I do.
Creates a property iota for a random Property. Costs about five [Charged Amethyst](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst) to etch this law into the universe.
Observes the current value of the property iota.
Sets the property iota. Costs about a tenth of an [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).
Creates a read-only property iota that refers to the same Property as the given property iota.
Imbues the supplied hexes into the amethyst equipment in my other hand, so that they will be cast whenever the item is used. Costs 9 charged amethyst except on arrows, which cost 5 shards.
Drops from the list iotas at the given indices. All other iotas are kept in the same order as the input.
Drops the first few elements from the input list; the dual to [Retention Distillation](https://hexic.pool.net.eu.org/v/1.4.2/1.0/en_us#addon/hexic/lists2@hexic:take/count).
Creates a new empty map for my usage.
Constructs a Patchwork iota from the userdata (iota stored inside), display iota (visible to my eyes), color, and an overload map.
Adds the phrase on the *tip of my tongue* to the stack, regardless of whether I intend to say it.
Converts a number into a Byte tag: an integer between -128 and 127, inclusive.
Converts a number into a Short tag, between -65536 and 65535.
Converts a number into an Int tag, between roughly negative 2 billion and positive 2 billion.
Converts a number into a Long tag: bounded to 9 quintillion, which I will likely never reach.
Converts a number into a Double tag. Oddly, doubles seem to perfectly correspond to my knowledge of numbers, plus the ability to represent infinities and non-numbers.
Converts a number into a Float tag. These seem similar to Doubles, albeit with less precision.

Takes a list of iotas (or a single non-iota, which is treated as a list with one element) and displays them permanently to the caster. Displayed iotas survive all methods that would clear a normal Reveal, and can only be cleared by another casting of Greater Reveal.
Rotates the array leftward: an argument of 1 moves the first item of the list to the end. Negative numbers allow rotating the list rightward.
Coerces my staff to cast a Hex. The hex uses the stack of the outer casting environment.
Coerces my staff to cast a Hex. The hex uses the stack of the staff itself, but keeps the outer environment's ravenmind.

Selects from the list only elements corresponding to the given indices. Unlike [Selection Distillation](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/lists@hexcasting:index), this cannot reorder or duplicate iotas.
Selects the first few elements from the input list. If the number is negative, selects the last few elements instead.
How could one even begin to draw this?
Restores the parchment of a scroll to an unmodified state.
Yellows the parchment of an Animated Scroll, making it bear striking semblance to some ancient scrolls I've been finding.
Causes the Animated Scroll to become invisible leaving only the pattern, making it appear as though the pattern were magically etched into the surface the scroll is on.
Changes the color of an Animated Scroll's ink to the color specified by the vector, with the components being 0 to 1 values of red, green, and blue respectively.
Causes the ink of an Animated Scroll to brightly glow, regardless of lighting conditions.
Associates a pattern to a list of patterns in the Grimoire in my offhand.
Erases any associations for a pattern that may exist in the Grimoire in my offhand.
Gets a list of all patterns modified by the Grimoire in my offhand.
Fortunately, the Art of Hexcasting is a versatile one and provides the means to bring back near anything.

Wish the genie to cast a Hex for me. Because I am *teaching* a mind rather than *etching* a [casting device](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/hexcasting), I can freely reteach the genie a new Hex any time without losing media.
Refuels the Lamp in my offhand by the given amount in [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst). Costs just the media I'm giving the Lamp.
Hold the lamp in my other hand and cast. Costs about ten [Charged Amethyst](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst) and requires the sacrifice.
Pushes my original position when I began using the Hand Lamp.
Pushes my original rotation when I began using the Hand Lamp.
Pushes my original velocity when I began using the Hand Lamp.
Pushes how many times the Hand Lamp has cast since I began using the Hand Lamp. I can divide by by 20 to convert to seconds.
Pushes the remaining media of the Hand Lamp, in units of dust.

Requests the iota I had saved to the genie to be pushed to the top of the stack. If I had not previously saved anything, the genie pushes [Null](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#casting/influences).
Asks the genie to remember an iota for me. Strangely, the genie seems able to bypass the Transgress Others mishap, perhaps because it requires my active concentration to use this Hand Lamp.
Pushes my original position when the [Archgenie Lamp](https://hexical.hexxy.media/v/latest/main/en_us#lamp/arch_lamps) started casting.
Pushes my original rotation when the [Archgenie Lamp](https://hexical.hexxy.media/v/latest/main/en_us#lamp/arch_lamps) started casting.
Pushes my original velocity when the [Archgenie Lamp](https://hexical.hexxy.media/v/latest/main/en_us#lamp/arch_lamps) started casting.
Pushes how many times the [Archgenie Lamp](https://hexical.hexxy.media/v/latest/main/en_us#lamp/arch_lamps) has cast since its activation. I can divide by by 20 to convert to seconds.

Can be cast by a [casting device](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/hexcasting), [Staff](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/staff), or within the [Archgenie Lamp](https://hexical.hexxy.media/v/latest/main/en_us#lamp/arch_lamps) to push the stored iota.

Can be cast by a [casting device](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/hexcasting), [Staff](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/staff), or within the [Archgenie Lamp](https://hexical.hexxy.media/v/latest/main/en_us#lamp/arch_lamps) to remember an iota. Unlike Hand Lamp, this is subject to Transgress Others mishap.
Pushes the remaining amount of media left in the [Archgenie Lamp](https://hexical.hexxy.media/v/latest/main/en_us#lamp/arch_lamps), in units of dust.
Pushes whether a player currently has an active [Archgenie Lamp](https://hexical.hexxy.media/v/latest/main/en_us#lamp/arch_lamps).
The instant I let go of my Hand Lamp, it casts an additional time. I can use this pattern to recognize whether a cast is that finale, and react accordingly.
Rotates a block to face a certain vector direction. Requires a rotatable block. Costs about an eighth of an [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).
Rotates an entity by a given change in pitch and yaw, expressed in radians.
Uses the number to shuffle the pattern into one of the same shape, but different stroke order. My notes hint that ancient Hexcasters used this for some *grand library*.
Pushes whether two patterns have the same shape, stroke order, and orientation.
Pushes whether two patterns have same shape but not necessarily the same stroke order.

Turns a pattern into a list of numbers for my splitting, analysis, and dissection. The inverse of [Calligrapher's Purification](https://hexical.hexxy.media/v/latest/main/en_us#patterns/pattern_manipulation@hexical:deserialize_pattern).

Turns a list of numbers into a pattern for my viewing and execution. The inverse of [Chirographer's Purification](https://hexical.hexxy.media/v/latest/main/en_us#patterns/pattern_manipulation@hexical:serialize_pattern).
Takes a pattern and produces a normalized list of vectors. The z-component of these vectors is zero. I feel this may be useful for artistic Hexes.

Pushes two lists; one of the stack and one of the unfinished list building after an unclosed [Introspection](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/patterns_as_iotas@hexcasting:open_paren). Entity references to players that are not me become [Null](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#casting/influences).

Takes two lists of iotas and sets them as my stack and my parenthesized list respectively. Entity references to players that are not me become [Null](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#casting/influences).
By focusing on a particular image, I can detect that concentration via this pattern. Pushes how many twentieths of a second I've been intending to Call Telepathy, or -1 if I am not.
Momentarily displays an iota above my hotbar. If cast repeatedly, each cast overwrites the previous instantly.
Grandly flashes an iota across my vision. It obstructs my vision and takes some time to fade in, so I shall only use it sparingly.
Causes me to hear a pling that is inaudible to others.
Causes me to hear a click that is inaudible to others.
Pushes how many twentieths of a second I've been intending to Attack/Destroy, or -1 if I am not.
Pushes how many twentieths of a second I've been intending to Use Item/Place Block, or -1 if I am not.
Pushes how many twentieths of a second I've been intending to Walk Forwards, or -1 if I am not.
Pushes how many twentieths of a second I've been intending to Walk Backwards, or -1 if I am not.
Pushes how many twentieths of a second I've been intending to Strafe Left, or -1 if I am not. Can be differentiated from Evade Reflection because d comes to the left of e.
Pushes how many twentieths of a second I've been intending to Strafe Right, or -1 if I am not. Can be differentiated from Dodge Reflection because e comes to the right of d.
Pushes how many twentieths of a second I've been intending to Jump, or -1 if I am not.
Pushes how many twentieths of a second I've been intending to Sneak, or -1 if I am not.
Pushes the change in scrolling I have performed since I have invoked Telepathy.
Reads the pattern key of an [Akashic Bookshelf](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#greatwork/akashiclib).
Reads the iota from an [Akashic Bookshelf](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#greatwork/akashiclib).
Writes an iota under a pattern key to an [Akashic Bookshelf](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#greatwork/akashiclib).
Clears an [Akashic Bookshelf](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#greatwork/akashiclib).

Conjures a Mage Blocks at the location. Costs about three [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).
*I can create a city out of nothing, or I can cover it in volcanic rock.*

Conjures a Mage Blocks at the location. Costs about three [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).
*I can create a city out of nothing, or I can cover it in volcanic rock.*
Makes the block bouncy, like a Slime Block. Bounces me regardless of whether I am sneaking. Delightfully fun!
Sets the duration after which a Mage Block will spontaneously disappear.
Sets the Redstone power outputted by this Mage Block.
Breaking volatile Mage Blocks shatters others it is touching. This can cascade until every connected volatile block shatters.

Autographs the item in my offhand with my name and [Pigment](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/pigments). Autographing an item with my name already on it moves my name to the top of the list.

A more destructive form of [Erase Item](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/spells/hexcasting@hexcasting:erase), capable of burning off autographs. Costs about one [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst) similar to [Erase Item](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/spells/hexcasting@hexcasting:erase).
Pushes whether a given player has signed a given item stack.
Gets the dye of a block, entity, or block/item identifier.
Dyes a dyeable block or entity. Costs about an eighth of one [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).
Translates a dye color into a vector, where each component is from 0 to 1 and represents the red, green, and blueness of the dye respectively.

Conjures a small silver of amethyst that always deals a full heart of damage and forces the target backwards. Costs about one [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).
Takes a colored dye iota and transforms it into a pigment, takes a player and returns their pigment, or takes an item containing a pigment and returns its pigment.
Samples the pigment at a certain place and time as a vector, where each component is from 0 to 1 and represents the red, green, and blueness respectively.
Internalizes a pigment iota.

Causes a small magical effect, not too distinct from the original nature or function of the target. Costs about a tenth of one [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).

This spell vanishes the stack of items in my other hand, or conjures it back, swapping if my other hand is holding something. Costs about a eighth of one [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).
Returns the item in my wristpocket, or [Null](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#casting/influences) if it is empty.

Performs an act of magical sleight of hand to steal items into my wristpocket or expel my wristpocket back into the world. Costs about a fourth of one [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).

Projects my mind's hand forward to use my wristpocketed item and interact with the world. If my wristpocket is empty, acts as though a plain hand had reached out. Costs about one [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).

Makes me eat my wristpocketed item, nourishing me or applying potions to me. Costs about one [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst) and mishaps if the item is not edible.
Conjures a speck with the iota, position, and rotation. Costs a negligible amount of media. Pushes the speck iota to the stack.
Changes the speck's iota.
Forces a speck to disappear.
Moves a speck entity to the position.
Rotates a speck entity to face the vector.
Accepts a number between 0 and 1, representing a fraction of a full rotation, and rotates the speck's image by that amount.
Scales the speck, can range from 0 to 10. Represents size in blocks and is zero by default.
Changes the stroke thickness of a pattern speck, can range from 0 to 10. Represents twentieths of a block, and is zero by default.
Commands the speck to disappear after that many twentieths of a second.
Splashes a pigment iota onto the speck, changing its color after creation.
Returns specks similarly to other [zone distillation](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/entities@hexcasting:zone_entity/animal) patterns.
Conjures an egg. May be fertile. Costs about two [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).
Conjures a sticky low-damaging projectile. Costs about a fourth of one [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).
Conjures a harmless snowball. Costs about half of an [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).
Conjures an explosive fireball that can be *percussively propelled*. Costs about three [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).

Creates a loud bang similar to that of [Fireworks](https://hexical.hexxy.media/v/latest/main/en_us#patterns/spells/pyrotechnics) and a burst of colorful particles, either in a direction or in a radial blast. Costs about half of one [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).

Causes a visible pulse of vibration from a vector to an entity or vector over a number of seconds. Costs about a sixteenth of one [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).
Produces a small sparkling particle of my desired position, color, and lifespan. Costs a negligible amount of media.

Cracks the unprogrammed [casting device](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/hexcasting) or [Curio](https://hexical.hexxy.media/v/latest/main/en_us#items/curios) in my offhand. Cracked casting devices proudly display their Hexes. Costs about one [Charged Amethyst](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).

Conjures a flower of my choosing at a location. I must have identified this flower at some point before. Costs about a quarter of an [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).

Conjures a completely invisible light with illumination strength of my choosing at a location. Costs about a quarter of an [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).
Instantly replenishes a creature's air bubbles. Costs about one [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).

Emits a sound associated with a mob near a location, as though a parrot had imitated that mob. Costs about a half of an [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).

Targets structural faults in a block, resulting in a higher yield. Costs about one, three, and five [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst) when power input is 0, 1, and 2 respectively.
Breaks a block gently, perserving the block better than standard mining. Costs about half of an [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).

Conjures a Hex Gummy: a delightful light snack that also provides about a tenth of an [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst)'s worth of media. Costs about one [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).

Conjures a Hexburst of the given iota at the location. Costs about one [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst) and is subject to the Transgress Others mishap.
Conjures a Hextito of the given Hex at the location. Costs about two [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst) and is subject to the Transgress Others mishap.

Takes a non-air position, an axis vector, and a delay in seconds up to ten seconds long and conjures a spike at that location. Costs about one [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).
Takes a block position and an axis vector and pushes the block along that vector. Costs an eighth of an [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).

Takes an item entity, a position, and an axis vector and dispenses the item. For most applications, costs about half of one [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).

Takes an item entity and cooks it as if in a Furnace. Costs about one [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst) for every ten seconds that the Furnace would need to have been active.

A specialized variant of [Cook](https://hexical.hexxy.media/v/latest/main/en_us#patterns/spells/block_mimicry@hexical:smelt) that simulates a Campfire instead. This has a much more limited set of possibilities; I am unsure why I would ever use this.

A specialized variant of [Cook](https://hexical.hexxy.media/v/latest/main/en_us#patterns/spells/block_mimicry@hexical:smelt) that simulates a Smoker instead, making it unable to process anything but foods but at a faster rate, making the spell cheaper.

A specialized variant of [Cook](https://hexical.hexxy.media/v/latest/main/en_us#patterns/spells/block_mimicry@hexical:smelt) that simulates a Blast Furnace instead, making it unable to process anything but ores but at a faster rate, making the spell cheaper.
Takes an item entity and cuts the item into the shape of an item identifier. Costs about an eighth of one [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).

Teleports an entity within the [circle](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#greatwork/spellcircles) to another point within the same [circle](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#greatwork/spellcircles). Unlike [Greater Teleport](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/great_spells/teleport), this spell takes in world coordinates rather than an offset. Costs about half of an [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).

Allows a [circle](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#greatwork/spellcircles) to hook onto a [Pedestal](https://hexical.hexxy.media/v/latest/main/en_us#items/pedestals) within ambit to use as its *other arm*. Useful for certain spells that demand an item held in my other hand. It also works as a [Wristpocket](https://hexical.hexxy.media/v/latest/main/en_us#patterns/spells/wristpocket).

Exports media out of an [Impetus](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#greatwork/impetus) at a rate of about eleven [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst) spent per ten [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst) created. Takes a location and a number of up to a stack of [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).
Pushes the Hex etched into my mind.

Etches a Hex, allowing me to cast it by holding Evoke for one second. Costs about one [Charged Amethyst](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).
*Anthony thought at it, and it turned a flip-flop on the grass, and lay trembling, its eyes gleaming in small black terror.*
Pushes how long since a player has been evoking. Is -1 if they are not currently evoking.
Conjures a firework of my *exact* specifications. It may be one of the most complex spells in existence. Costs equivalently to the other firework spell.
operators.inputs: vec, vec, num, num, list of vec, list of vec, bool, bool

operators.description: Analyzes the Firework Star in my other hand and conjures a firework of that star, with the position, velocity, and gunpowder amount specified. Costs about one [Amethyst Shard](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).
Pushes a number relating to which of my current items I am currently holding.

Takes a number 0 to 8 and switches my current item to it.
*Remember, switching to your pistol is always faster than reloading.*
Dismisses any existing Lesser Sentinels and deploys a Lesser Sentinel at every position in the list.
Returns a list of vectors corresponding to the positions of all my Lesser Sentinels.
Takes an item and renames it to the text given. Resets name if given [Null](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#casting/influences). Free.
Takes an item and a list of text to append as a description. Clears if given [Null](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#casting/influences). Free.
Breaks any shader spell currently applied to me. Useful for "bleaching" my eyes after too much experimentation.
Greatly augments my ability to see in the dark, although the light resultingly becomes extremely blinding.
Transforms the world into a thin outline of black and white. Possibly useful for identifying subtle contrasts.
Alters my vision to contain strange lines and make objects towards the center of my vision bulge "towards" me. Seems to be in reference to something...
Transforms my vision to perceive only the most important things...
Splits my vision into multiple sections, similar to what a spider might see. I am unsure whether it actually grants me more vision...

Instantly transports all items from source to destination. Cost scales based on the amount of mass transferred - a stack of 64 items will cost about three [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst). Numbers are optional; details later.
Applies to sources that support slots; inventories. Returns a list of the item stacks contained within them, with their index in the list being their slot number.
Judging by the pattern signature, I can only imagine that it summons something.

Charms an item. Takes the item to charm, the Hex, and an amount of media in [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst). Consumes that amount and about three [Charged Amethyst](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).
operators.inputs: entity, list, num, list of num, list of num

operators.description: Writes an iota to the charmed item’s internal storage. Subject to the Transgress Others mishap.
Pushes the stored iota from the charmed item’s internal storage.
If the item charged features an iota storage by default, such as a [Focus](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/focus), writes an iota into it.
If the item charged features an iota storage by default, such as a [Focus](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/focus), reads an iota from it.
Removes a charm from an item without affecting any other property. Costs about one [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).
Teleports me up to 128 blocks away, relative to my position and rotation. Costs about two [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).
Conjures a mesh with the location and leaves a mesh entity on the stack. Costs about one [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).
Takes a list of vectors, with constraints defined on the prior page, and weaves the mesh into that shape. Free.
Pushes the shape of a mesh as a list of vectors.
Commands a Ballast on my person to fall in a given direction with a given strength strength. Free.
Takes an entity, an axial vector for new gravity, and a strength scalar relative to standard pull. Specifics are detailed on the next page.

Pushes the remaining twentieths of a second that [Gravitate](https://miyucomics.github.io/hexodus/v/1.0.0/1.0.0/en_us#patterns/spells/gravity@hexodus:change_gravity) will affect an entity. Zero if the entity is not under the effects of [Gravitate](https://miyucomics.github.io/hexodus/v/1.0.0/1.0.0/en_us#patterns/spells/gravity@hexodus:change_gravity).

Pushes the direction that [Gravitate](https://miyucomics.github.io/hexodus/v/1.0.0/1.0.0/en_us#patterns/spells/gravity@hexodus:change_gravity) is attempting to drag an entity, or [Null](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#casting/influences) if the entity is not under the effects of [Gravitate](https://miyucomics.github.io/hexodus/v/1.0.0/1.0.0/en_us#patterns/spells/gravity@hexodus:change_gravity).

Pushes the scaling factor of [Gravitate](https://miyucomics.github.io/hexodus/v/1.0.0/1.0.0/en_us#patterns/spells/gravity@hexodus:change_gravity)'s gravity compared to baseline, or [Null](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#casting/influences) if the entity is not under the effects of [Gravitate](https://miyucomics.github.io/hexodus/v/1.0.0/1.0.0/en_us#patterns/spells/gravity@hexodus:change_gravity).
Pushes the direction of Gravity acting on an entity.
Pushes strength of Gravity acting on an entity compared to baseline.
Pushes whether the given player has achieved Enlightenment.

Pushes whether an entity has been "magically relieved of its mind". I feel this is strongly related to [Flay Mind](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/great_spells/brainsweep) somehow...

Takes an iota and returns a [text iota](https://miyucomics.github.io/hexpose/v/1.0.0/1.0.0/en_us#patterns/text_iotas) representing it. If taking a [text iota](https://miyucomics.github.io/hexpose/v/1.0.0/1.0.0/en_us#patterns/text_iotas), strips all the styles of it.
Splits a [text iota](https://miyucomics.github.io/hexpose/v/1.0.0/1.0.0/en_us#patterns/text_iotas) into a list of individual glyphs.
Transforms all the elements of a list into text (or keeps them if they were) and pastes it all together.

Takes a [text iota](https://miyucomics.github.io/hexpose/v/1.0.0/1.0.0/en_us#patterns/text_iotas) and a color encoded as a vector whose components range from 0 to 1, and produces a [text iota](https://miyucomics.github.io/hexpose/v/1.0.0/1.0.0/en_us#patterns/text_iotas) of that color.
Takes a [text iota](https://miyucomics.github.io/hexpose/v/1.0.0/1.0.0/en_us#patterns/text_iotas) and sets whether it is **bold**.
Takes a [text iota](https://miyucomics.github.io/hexpose/v/1.0.0/1.0.0/en_us#patterns/text_iotas) and sets whether it is in *italics*.
Takes a [text iota](https://miyucomics.github.io/hexpose/v/1.0.0/1.0.0/en_us#patterns/text_iotas) and sets whether it is __underlined__.
Takes a [text iota](https://miyucomics.github.io/hexpose/v/1.0.0/1.0.0/en_us#patterns/text_iotas) and sets whether it has been ~~struck through~~.
Takes a [text iota](https://miyucomics.github.io/hexpose/v/1.0.0/1.0.0/en_us#patterns/text_iotas) and sets whether it is obfusca||ted||.
Works similar to [Archer's Distillation](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/basics@hexcasting:raycast) but targets only liquids, piercing through all other blocks.
Works similar to [Architect's Distillation](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/basics@hexcasting:raycast/axis) but targets only liquids, piercing through all other blocks.

Works similar to [Archer's Distillation](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/basics@hexcasting:raycast) but accepts an additional identifier. It will pierce all blocks until it hits the block specified by the identifier.

Works similar to [Architect's Distillation](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/basics@hexcasting:raycast/axis) but accepts an additional identifier. It will pierce all blocks until it hits the block specified by the identifier.
Pushes how difficult blocks of this type are to mine.
Pushes how resistant blocks of this type are to explosions.
Pushes the vector of the block's facing direction, or [Null](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#casting/influences) if blocks of its type do not have an orientation.
Pushes a number 0 to 1 corresponding to the growth progress of that block. Works for crops, Beehives, Composters, Cauldrons, and strangely Cakes too.
Pushes a list of all facets of that block.
Takes a block and a facet and pushes that facet's value.
Pushes the color blocks of this type appear as on a map.

Applies [News Reflection](https://miyucomics.github.io/hexpose/v/1.0.0/1.0.0/en_us#patterns/scrying/chat@hexpose:get_message) to the last up to 32 messages in chat, wraps each in a list, and pushes a list of those lists.

Pushes a [text iota](https://miyucomics.github.io/hexpose/v/1.0.0/1.0.0/en_us#patterns/text_iotas) of the last person to use chat, a [text iota](https://miyucomics.github.io/hexpose/v/1.0.0/1.0.0/en_us#patterns/text_iotas) of the message, and a number of twenieths of a second since that message sent.
Gets a list of enchantments the item has.
Gets the strength of the specific enchantment on the item.
Similar to [Stadiometer's Purification](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/basics@hexcasting:get_entity_height) but pushes the width of an entity rather than its height.

Similar to [Alidade's Purification](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/basics@hexcasting:get_entity_look) but pushes the vector that points upwards from their head rather than the entity's facing vector.
Pushes how close an entity is to death. I can think of these in terms of half-hearts.
Pushes how much health an entity can have at its prime. I can think of these in terms of half-hearts.
Pushes the number of seconds the burning entity will continue burning if not put out. -1 if the entity is not burning currently.
Pushes whether the entity is touching rain, water, or in a bubble column.
Pushes the number of seconds before an entity will start to suffocate. This applies to marine creatures out of water as well as land creatures in water.
Pushes the number of seconds a regular entity of that type can last outside their normal breathing environment before they start suffocating.
Pushes whether the Player, Cat, Fox, or other entity is sleeping.
Pushes whether the Player, Cat, Fox, or other entity is sprinting. Swimming and leaving the ground after starting to sprint are still included.
Pushes whether a living creature is a baby. Also works on Armor Stands oddly.

Pushes whether an animal creature is in love and ready to mate, or [Null](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#casting/influences) if that creature is not capable of that type of reproduction.
Pushes how full a Player is. I can think of this in terms of half-hunches.
Pushes a Player's saturation, which roughly correlates to how long the Player will remain full.
Pushes the entity the given entity is riding or [Null](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#casting/influences) if it is not riding in or on anything.
Pushes a list of entities that are riding the given entity.

Pushes the shooter of the given projectile entity or [Null](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#casting/influences) if it has no shooter or isn't a projectile. It also pushes [Null](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#casting/influences) if the shooter is outside my ambit.
Pushes the player that has tamed this animal, or [Null](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#casting/influences) if it is untamed or the player is out of ambit.
Pushes the number of magical hearts this player has. I can think of these in terms of half-hearts.
Pushes whether a location or entity is in ambit.
Pushes whether a [Staff](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/staff) is being used to cast this pattern.
Pushes whether the dominant hand of the caster is being used to cast this pattern. May return strange results for casters without hands.
Pushes whether any form of [casting device](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/hexcasting) is being used to cast this pattern.
Pushes whether some form of [*grand work*](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#greatwork/spellcircles) is being used to cast this pattern.
Takes in an item identifier and pushes whether I can eat it.
Takes in an item identifier and pushes the amount it will fill me.
Takes in an item identifier and pushes the saturation value, which roughly affects how long it will fill me.
Takes in an item identifier and pushes whether it's considered a meat. Wolves can eat meats.
Takes in an item identifier and pushes whether it's a snack.
Pushes the identifier of an entity or block at a vector.
Pushes the identifier of an iota's type. Can be used to determine whether two iota are the same type.
Pushes the item that an Item in the world is.
Creates an item iota from an item identifier and the number of items in the stack.
Returns the item in the entity's mainhand.
Returns the item in the entity's offhand.
Returns a list of all items the entity is wearing, from feet up.
Returns a list of all items in my ender chest.

Returns a list of all items the entity is carrying, or [Null](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#casting/influences) if the entity can not hold items. Trying to access another Player's inventory will incur a mishap.
Returns a list of all items in the container, or [Null](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#casting/influences) if the block can not contain items.
Takes in an item and pushes how many items are in it.
Takes in an item and pushes how many items that can stack in it.
Takes in an item and pushes how much damage the item has sustained.
Takes in an item and pushes how much durability the item can have at its peak.

If this item is subceptible to [Caster's Glamour](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/spells/cyclevariant), pushes the index of the current form it's taking on. Otherwise pushes [Null](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#casting/influences).

If this item is subceptible to [Caster's Glamour](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/spells/cyclevariant), pushes the number of forms it's capable of. Otherwise pushes [Null](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#casting/influences).
Gets the name given to this item.
Gets the lore written into this item.

Pushes a list of [text iotas](https://miyucomics.github.io/hexpose/v/1.0.0/1.0.0/en_us#patterns/text_iotas) contained inside a book or [Null](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#casting/influences) if it isn't a book.
Pushes the author of a book and its generation number.
Gauges the rarity of an item as a number, with greater values corresponding to a rarer item. Certain aspects such as enchantments can also elevate an item's rarity.
Pushes a list of status effects the entity is afflicted with.
Pushes a list of status effects the food or potion will bestow.
Pushes the general "goodness" of the effect towards the afflicted. -1 for harmful, 0 for neutral, and 1 for beneficial.
Pushes how potent the effect type is acting on the entity or [Null](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#casting/influences) if the entity doesn't have it.
Pushes how long the effect type will affect the entity in twentieths of a second or [Null](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#casting/influences) if the entity doesn't have it.
Pushes how advanced a villager is as a number, encoding mastery of their craft.
Pushes the profession of a villager as an identifier
Pushes the ambient cultural aspect tied to the villager’s origin, such as desert or taiga roots.
Projects the villager archetype most attuned to the essence of the specified biome, or [Null](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#casting/influences) if none can be drawn.
Pushes the amount of media inside an item, that a creature contains or holds, or that a specialized media-holding block contains.
Pushes the media available to the current cast.

Takes in an item and pushes either [Null](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#casting/influences) if the item does not have any media-holding potential, or the amount of media it is capable of holding at its peak.
Pushes a number corresponding to the weather. 0 for clear, 1 for rain, and 2 for thundering.
Pushes the light level at the position as a number 0 to 15. If inside a nontransparent block, it returns zero.
Pushes the Redstone power that a position receives.
Pushes the power level a Comparator would output if pressed against a position.
Pushes the progress of the day as a number between 0 (start) and 1 (end) of the day.
Pushes the twentieths of a second since the creation of the world, unaffected by events such as sleeping.
Pushes the current phase of the Moon as a fraction of its size.
Pushes the identifier of the type of biome the vector is within.
Pushes the identifier of the dimension the Hex is being cast in.
Pushes whether Compasses and Clocks will work in this dimension.
Pushes the variant of the Cat.
Pushes the progress of a Creeper to explosion.
Pushes the rotation of an Item Frame as an integer 0 to 7.
Pushes the variant of the Painting.
Compels my mind to Dash according to the normalized vector. Cancels my velocity if given the zero vector. Free. If I am out of Dashes, does nothing. Requires Estrogen.

Instantly replenishes all of the player's Dashes. Costs about one [Charged Amethyst](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst). Nature *really* doesn't want me to dash infinitely, it seems. Requires Estrogen.
Creates a new room for me
Lets actually go there
You are going to ~~Brazil~~, ~~My Domain~~, *T H E   F U N   Z O N E*
G E T   O U T
Roommates perhaps?
Custom door location?
This should make things easier
I can access blocks easier
My own personal casting space
Look Ma two dimensions
Are we done yet
How much longer must I wait

Causes the villager to seek out its bed and take a short nap. Not effective if the villager lacks a bed to use. Costs one [Charged Amethyst](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).
Pushes a list of iotas representing all my embedded minds.
Pushes the Hex stored in the provided mind, or [Null](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#casting/influences) if there isn't one.
Stores the provided Hex into the mind. If there is already a stored Hex, it will be overwritten. Costs one [Charged Amethyst](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).
Pushes the trigger stored in the provided mind, or [Null](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#casting/influences) if there isn't one.
Stores the provided trigger into the mind. If the mind already has a trigger, it will be overwritten. Costs one [Amethyst Shard](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).
Suppresses sound and particles from the provided mind's casting, based on the state of the bool. If true, the mind will be muted; if false, it will be unmuted.

Permanently removes an embedded mind from my own consciousness.
I wonder what happens to them, when they go?

When I die, my embedded minds become unstable and cease to function. This spell restores them to working order. Costs one [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst) per mind restored.
Creates a trigger that activates whenever I take damage. To prevent a lethal chain-reaction, does not activate if the damage was caused by overcasting.
Creates a trigger that activates whenever I take damage, but only if the damage was of a specific type. The trigger will be attuned to whatever type of damage I last received.
Creates a trigger that activates when my health drops below the specified value. A full, standard healthbar has a value of 20.
Creates a trigger that activates when my breath drops below the specified value. A full bar of bubbles has a value of 10.
Creates a trigger that activates when my hunger drops below the specified value. A full hunger bar has a value of 20.
Creates a trigger that activates when my velocity (measured in blocks per tick) exceeds the specified value.
Creates a trigger that activates when I fall further than the specified number of blocks.

Creates a trigger that activates whenever I drop an item. This does **not** include involuntary dropping, such as on death or when using [Greater Teleport](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/great_spells/teleport).
Creates a trigger that activates whenever I strike another entity.
Creates a trigger that activates whenever I break a block.
Creates a trigger that activates whenever I jump.
Creates a trigger that activates whenever I teleport. For reasons I cannot discern, this will not detect teleports shorter than 1.5 blocks in length.
Inverts the threshold on a numerical trigger. For example, 'When velocity exceeds 5.0' will become 'When velocity drops below 5.0'. Has no effect on other types of triggers.

Read a list iota out of an entity or block, then push the iota at the specified index to the stack.
It seems this and the next pattern may be useful for handling large amounts of data without causing a [Too Many Iotas](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#casting/mishaps) mishap.
Read a list iota out of an entity or block, then set the element at the specified index of that list to the given iota, then write the resulting list back to the entity or block.
Transform all the Lapis Lazuli in my other hand into a loosely-held material called Amethyst Lazuli or Amel for short. Costs twice the number of Amethyst Shards as Lapis Lazuli in my offhand.

Transform all the Amethyst Lazuli in my other hand into Amethyst Shards. The Lapis turns into a fine mist which spreads quickly in the air. Excess shards spill onto the ground. Costs one Amethyst Shard.
While I could shape Amel into whatever I want, I have decided on four primary shapes which are familiar to me. I can use this pattern to mold the Amel in my offhand for free.
Pass in an entity and a number of half-hearts, and it enchants that entity's skin thus increasing their health. The Amel cost is the number given and the cost in media is twice the expended Amel.

Pass in an entity and a number of half-hearts, and it enchants that entity's fists thus increasing their damage per hit. One Amel and five Amethyst Shards per half-heart. Limit is four times the norm or just four for me.
Enchants the given entity's feet to increase their movement speed. Costs 1x Amel and 5x Amethyst Shards. Limit is 3x the norm. The norm for me is about 1.
Enchants the given *player's* arms, increasing their attack speed. Costs 1x Amel and 16x Amethyst Shards. Limit is 4 PLUS the norm.

Gives you the amount the given entity has been enhanced in the given area (specified by number). The patterns before were sorted so 0 gives max health, 1 gives attack damage and so on. Negligible media cost.
ENCHANT AN ENTITY'S FISTS WITH FIRE, AND IT WILL HENCEFORTH LIGHT ANY ENTITIES IT HITS ON FIRE FOR THREE SECONDS. CONSUMES 10 CHARGED AMETHYST. HAS 1 LEVEL. ID = 0.
ENCHANT AN ENTITY'S FISTS WITH LIGHTNING. CONSUMES 20 CHARGED AMETHYST PER LEVEL. 3 LEVELS, EACH IMPROVING THE USER'S ABILITY TO CHANNEL LIGHTNING. ID = 1.
ENVELOP FEET WITH AMEL THAT SPROUTS OUT TO BREAK ANY FALL 10 BLOCKS (PER LEVEL) OR BELOW. NO DAMAGE REDUCTION. TWO LEVELS. 5 CHARGED AMETHYST AND 32 AMEL PER LEVEL. ID = 2.
GIVES ME MORE LUNG CAPACITY, SIMILAR TO THE RESPIRATION ENCHANTMENT BUT TWICE AS STRONG. TWO LEVELS. 1 CHARGED AMETHYST AND 10 AMEL PER LEVEL. ID = 3.
WIELD THE ENERGY OF AN ENTIRE STACK OF AMEL AND TEN PIECES OF CHARGED AMETHYST TO MAKE ONE HELL-BORNE! (FIRE WILL NO LONGER HURT THEM) ID = 4.
GIVEN AN ENTITY AND AN ENCHANTMENT ID, GIVES THE LEVEL OF THE ENCHANTMENT ON THE ENTITY FOR NEGLIGIBLE COST. NO AMEL REQUIRED. DOES NOT REQUIRE AN ENLIGHTENED MIND.

The spell the ancient "Lapisworkers" would use very often. Imbue the item in my other hand (or main if nothing imbueable is in the other hand) with the specified amount of Amel, with no waste like the Enchant X spells. Costs 2x the amount of Amel being infused, in dust.

Pass in a vector within Ambit and a dye color, to conjure a fragile but solid, colored block. This costs two amethyst dust and the number states which dye I want to dye the colored block. More explanation on the next page.
Evaluates (exactly like Thoth's Gambit) the given pattern list over a hollow sphere with the given radius (non-decimal, at least 1, at most 64) around the given position.
Evaluates (exactly like Thoth's Gambit) the given pattern list over a (hollow if given True) cube-ish area from the given points A to B.
Negligible cost. Answers the question, "is there nothing there or between this place and there?". Both vectors must be in my ambit. Requires a player to cast it.
Specific hand version of Scribe's Reflection. Pushes the Iota stored in the Iota holder in the specified hand to the stack.
Specific hand version of Auditor's Reflection. Pushes whether the item in the specified hand can be read from or not.
Specific hand version of Scribe's Gambit. Writes the given Iota to the Iota holder in the specified hand.
Specific hand version of Assessor's Reflection. Pusher whether the item in the specified hand can be written to or not.
Returns whether the two blocks are equivalent/roughly equal (the same kind of block), so wheat seeds equals a full wheat crop. Both blocks must be within my ambit.
Returns whether the two blocks are **exactly** equal, so wheat seeds do NOT equal a full wheat crop. Blocks must be within my ambit.
Sieves the torrent of information using the (full) artificial mind at the given position. 3/5 chance of replacing the pattern in my other hand with one of the correct stroke order.
Absorbs the entirety of the mind within the container into the rechargeable item in my other hand. If there is any extra, it is discarded. A full container yields one Charged Amethyst.
Pushes the percentage filled of the mind container at the given position to the stack.
Teach the Live Jukebox at that location these notes (a list of whole numbers 0-24) at this frequency (0-20). After being hit via Use, it plays the notes like an automatic Note Block.
Peacefully put my Enchanted Sentinel to rest for a negligible amount of media, letting it rest for a time. Perhaps the ethical option, considering "falling apart" may not be the most painless.
Banish another's Enchanted Sentinel if it's at that block for 5 dust.

Pass in an entity within ambit and a vec, and the entity's fractional position will change to the vector (clamped). A number means a vec with all the components set to it. Negligible cost, but disappointing.

Takes an entity that will be within my ambit before and after teleportation and an offset vector, the length of which must be no greater than 10. Teleports the entity in that direction. Costs one shard.
Add an empty string to the stack, useful for combining with other strings.
Add a blank space string to the stack, useful for combining with other strings.
Add a comma string to the stack, useful for combining with other strings.
Add a string to the stack representing a break between lines, useful for combining with other strings.
Removes a vector from the stack. If that vector is pointing at a sign or lectern, it returns that sign or lectern's text to the stack. Otherwise, it returns null.

Removes a vector and a string from the stack. If that vector is pointing at a sign or lectern, it writes that string to that sign or lectern. Costs a hundredth of an [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).
Adds the last message the caster sent to the stack as a string.
Adds the last message anyone sent to the stack as a string.
Returns the last string you passed to [Sifter's Gambit](https://moreiotas.hexxy.media/v/0.1.1/1.0/en_us#patterns/strings@moreiotas:string/chat/prefix/set).

Accepts a string; All future chat messages starting with that string won't be seen by others, and only messages prefixed with that string can be read by [Whisper Reflection](https://moreiotas.hexxy.media/v/0.1.1/1.0/en_us#patterns/strings@moreiotas:string/chat/caster).
Converts the iota on top of the stack into a string.
Converts the pattern on top of the stack into the string for that pattern's name. If there is no action associated with that pattern, or if the associated pattern is a Great Spell, it returns null.
Takes an entity and returns that entity's name. If it is an item entity, return the item's name.

Takes a string and an entity, and sets that entities name to the given string. If the entity is an item entity, also set the item's name. Costs a hundredth of an [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).
Removes the top two strings from the stack and splits the first string, using the second string as the delimiter and returning as a list.
Removes a string from the top of the stack and returns the number that string parses as (or null if it doesn't parse).
Removes a string and a bool or null. If it was true, return the string in upper case. If false, lowercase. If null, toggle each character's case.
Multiplies the first n by m matrix elementwise with another n by m matrix.
Divides the first n by m matrix elementwise by another n by m matrix.
Raises the first n by m matrix elementwise to the power of another n by m matrix.
Converts the iota on top of the stack into a matrix. This iota can be a number, vector, or list.
Converts the iota on top of the stack back from a matrix into a number, vector, or list depending on the vector's size.
As [Restoration Purification](https://moreiotas.hexxy.media/v/0.1.1/1.0/en_us#patterns/matrices@moreiotas:matrix/unmake), except it always returns a list of lists of numbers.
Accepts a positive integer n, and returns an n by n matrix with 1 along the diagonal and 0 elsewhere.
Accepts positive integers n and m, and returns an n by m matrix of zeros.
Accepts a vec v and number θ, and returns a matrix representing rotating by θ radians around v.
Accepts an n by n matrix and returns the n by n matrix such that in\*out = identity.
Accepts a square matrix and returns the determinant of that matrix. Mishaps for matrices larger than 4x4.
Accepts an n by m matrix and a p by m matrix and produces a (n+p) by m matrix by putting the first matrix on top of the second.
Accepts an n by m matrix and an n by p matrix and produces an n by (m+p) matrix by putting the first matrix to the left of the second.
Accepts an n by m matrix and an int from 0 to n, and returns two matrices created by splitting the input matrix vertically at the inputted int.
Accepts an n by m matrix and an int from 0 to m, and returns two matrices created by splitting the input matrix horizontally at the inputted int.
Transforms the [Item Stack](https://moreiotas.hexxy.media/v/0.1.1/1.0/en_us#casting/item_iotas) at the top of the stack into its Item.

Remove an iota with an associated item type (for example a location and the type of the block at that location, an item entity, or an item frame) from the stack and returns the item type to the stack (e.g. Grass, Stone, Stick, etc.).
Accepts a mote and returns an [Item Stack](https://moreiotas.hexxy.media/v/0.1.1/1.0/en_us#casting/item_iotas) representing the items in the record referenced by that mote.
Remove an entity from the stack, and adds the type of the entity at that location to the stack.
Remove an iota from the stack, and adds the type of that iota to the stack.
Adds the type of the item in the caster's offhand to the stack if there is one present, or the type of the casting hand otherwise.
Remove an entity type and a position from the stack, and returns an entity of that type at that position if one exists.
Remove an entity type, a position, and a radius from the stack, and returns a list of all entities of that type within that radius of that position.
Remove an entity type, a position, and a radius from the stack, and returns a list of all entities not of that type within that radius of that position
Transforms the entity at the top of the stack into the Item Stack in its main hand. Also works on Item Frames and dropped items.
Transforms the entity at the top of the stack into the Item Stack in its off hand.
Removes two vectors from the stack representing position and side. Returns a list of Item Stacks in the block at the given position accessible from the given side (or all if second vector is zero).
Removes two vectors from the stack representing position and side. Returns a list of Items in the block at the given position accessible from the given side (or all if second vector is zero).
Removes the number at the top of the stack, then sets the size of the Item Stack at the top of the stack to that number.
Returns a Spatial Imprint representing the dimension I am currently in. Costs a negligible amount of media.
Returns a Spatial Imprint representing the dimension my sentinel is currently in. Costs one-tenth of an amethyst dust.
Returns a Spatial Imprint representing the overworld. Costs one-tenth of an amethyst dust.

Returns a Spatial Imprint representing the nether. Costs one-tenth of an amethyst dust.
There seems to be some resistance when I cast this. Perhaps I'll be able to overcome it with greater skill...
Accepts a Spatial Imprint, and returns the lowest and highest altitudes at which blocks can exist in the corresponding dimension.
Accepts a Spatial Imprint, and returns how many blocks you'd have to travel in the overworld to travel the equivalent of one block in the input dimension.
When cast with a Reverberation Rod, returns my look vector from when I started the current cast loop.
When cast with a Reverberation Rod, returns my eye position from when I started the current cast loop.
When cast with a Reverberation Rod, returns the timestamp from when I started the current cast loop.
Returns the iota stored in the current cast loop. Defaults to NULL.
Accepts a non-list iota, and stores it inside the current cast loop. It will be lost when the cast loop ends.
As Williams' Reflection, but can be cast from non-rod sources while a rod is in use.
As Williams' Gambit, but can be cast from non-rod sources while a rod is in use.
Accepts a valid key, and returns the corresponding iota. Costs one-eigth of an amethyst dust.
Accepts a valid key, and returns when the corresponding iota was inscribed, or -1. Costs no media.
Accepts a valid key and a player, and returns whether the corresponding iota was inscribed by that player. Costs no media.
Accepts a vector and a player, and returns either the distance from the vector to the target player's sentinel or NULL. Costs a negligible amount of media.
Accepts a vector and a number, and returns a list of unit vectors pointing from the initial vector to shrouded entities within a radius defined by the number.
Accepts a positive integer. When cast with a Reverberation Rod, delays the current cast loop's next cast until that many twentieths of a second have passed.
When cast with a Reverberation Rod, forcibly halts the current cast loop.
Accepts a positive integer. Halts the current cast loop but also reduces the cooldown period from 1 second to ((1/20) \* number) seconds. Cooldown due to mishap is unaffected.
Returns a boolean corresponding to whether the current cast is making use of a rod.
Returns whether the caster is currently using a rod, regardless of the current cast is from that rod.
Accepts a valid key and any iota, and stores it in the corresponding location. Costs a quarter of an amethyst dust.
Acts just like [the spells used to program conventional casting items](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/spells/hexcasting). Costs 10 Charged Amethyst.
Writes a hex to the bottomless trinket in my other hand. Costs ten charged amethyst.

Accepts an entity and a Spatial Imprint and teleports the entity to its position in the proper dimension. Generally costs 20 Charged Amethyst.
Will fail if supplied a player other than myself.
Accepts a vector and infuses media into the corresponding block in order to transmute it. Cost and exact effect vary depending on target.
Accepts two lists of two vectors, to define two cuboids, and a Spatial Imprint. These cuboids must have the exact same dimensions and rotation.
Accepts a living entity and a number (*n*), and shields the entity from hex-based detection for *n* seconds. Costs two amethyst dust per second.
Accepts a living entity, and allows it to be accessed from anywhere for one minute. Has a base cost of one amethyst shard, plus one additional shard per application before allowing it to expire.
Accepts an item or item frame bearing the Sharpness enchantment, and converts it into Mind Render of the same level. Cost is based on enchantment level, and increases by 50% if the item is a book.
Accepts a flayed mob, and creates an artifical pseudo-mind to inhabit its body. Costs 16 charged amethyst when used on a villager or allay, or 10 amethyst shards for anything else.
A strange pattern that appears to be a variant of Hermes' Gambit. Accepts a spatial imprint and an executable iota, and attempts to cast the iota in the corresponding dimension.
Accepts a spatial imprint, and moves my sentinel to its scaled coordinates in the corresponding dimension. Costs one amethyst shard. Mishaps if I do not currently have a sentinel.
Reflects the order of the top three iota, turning A, B, C into C, B, A. Essentially swaps the top and the third-from-the-top iota.
Causes the third-from-the-top iota to bubble up over the second-from-the-top iota, essentially swapping them.
Takes a number and duplicates that many elements of the stack while preserving order.
Creates a jumble iota corresponding to the argument count and the list of numbers.
Dissolves a jumble iota back into a number and a list of numbers.
Pushes soroban's current value and then increases it. Starts at 0.
Resets the soroban to 0.
Pops a number from the stack and sets the soroban to it.
Folds across the first list using the Hex in the second list.
Casts a list of patterns similar to [Hermes' Gambit](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/meta@hexcasting:eval) but allows for handling of mishaps.
Reveals to me the last mishap caught by [Athena's Gambit](https://miyucomics.github.io/overevaluate/v/latest/main/en_us#metaevals@overevaluate:athena) within this Hex.

Pushes the last mishap caught by [Athena's Gambit](https://miyucomics.github.io/overevaluate/v/latest/main/en_us#metaevals@overevaluate:athena) as *text* if the appropriate powers are active in this world.

Should only be run inside [Thoth's](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/meta@hexcasting:for_each) or [Sisyphus' Gambit](https://miyucomics.github.io/overevaluate/v/latest/main/en_us#metaevals@overevaluate:sisyphus). Acts similarly to [Charon's Gambit](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/meta@hexcasting:halt) except does not end the iterator, only skips the rest of the current iteration.
Should only be run within a [Thoth's](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/meta@hexcasting:for_each). Details on the next page. Beware of triggering the Delve Too Deep mishap.

Sibling pattern to [Castor's Gambit](https://miyucomics.github.io/overevaluate/v/latest/main/en_us#metaevals@overevaluate:castor), this pattern schedules the additional iteration for the end instead. Carries the same risk of encountering the Delve Too Deep mishap.
Instantly terminates the Hex regardless of current circumstances.
Takes a boolean and any iota. If the boolean is false, mishaps and prints the iota.

Takes a pattern list and casts it over and over forever until it encounters either a [Charon's Gambit](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/meta@hexcasting:halt) or a [Janus' Gambit](https://miyucomics.github.io/overevaluate/v/latest/main/en_us#metaevals@overevaluate:janus).

Takes a list and a pattern or pattern list which is used to sort the list by casting over every iota similar to [Thoth's Gambit](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/meta@hexcasting:for_each).
Does nothing.
Returns the full width and height of my vision as a vector.
Pushes a list of the indices of all the Icons I have. This appears as a list of numbers.
Immediately clears an Icon.
Takes an index, a position, a number, and any iota. Conjures an Icon displaying that iota.
Takes an index, a position, a size, and a color. Conjures an Icon displaying that rectangle.
Takes an index, a position, a size, and a color. Conjures an Icon that joins between the two with a thin line.
Takes an index and an amount of rotation counterclockwise in terms of a full circle. Rotates the icon.
Takes an index and a scaling factor. Scales the icon.

It is much easier to store an item into a Vessel than to pull it out. This pattern simply takes an Item Entity, and neatly sorts it into the activated Storage Vessels. Costs an 1/8th of a [dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst) per activated Vessel.

This simply returns what Vessels the current [Spell Circle](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#greatwork/spellcircles) has activated. I should likely use this to check if the [Spell Circle](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#greatwork/spellcircles) has collected any Vessels.

This takes a Hex and runs it on every [Item Stack](https://miyucomics.github.io/hexpose/v/1.0.0/1.0.0/en_us#patterns/scrying/item) stored (with it on top of the stack). Once the Hex is executed, it requires a Integer, Vector, and Boolean, left on the stack, in that order.
Check Item functions much like Reawaken Item; however, it only requires a Boolean from the inputted Hex. If the Boolean is ever True, the spell ends, and returns True.

In some rare scenarios, Vessels can get jumbled up and have items of the same type spread across different  Vessels. This is a neat spell to resort them at a cost. That cost being 5 [Charged Amethyst](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).

Sets the crafting recipe of a [Patterned Assembler](https://stick404.github.io/SlateWork/v/1.0.3/1.0/en_us#greatwork/crafting_loci). Takes a list of [Nulls](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#casting/influences), items, or item variants, and applies it to the targeted [Assembler](https://stick404.github.io/SlateWork/v/1.0.3/1.0/en_us#greatwork/crafting_loci).

This binds both a pattern and an iota to a [Spell Imprinter](https://stick404.github.io/SlateWork/v/1.0.3/1.0/en_us#greatwork/macro_loci), which is at the targeted vector. 
Does not mishap if casted outside of a [Spell Circle](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#greatwork/spellcircles). Costs a negligible amount of media.
This takes a list of vectors, and attempts to move the Pseudosentinels to the positions.
This retrieves the current positions of all Pseudosentinels in the order they were awoken. Free to cast.

Attempts to read an [Iotic Door](https://stick404.github.io/SlateWork/v/1.0.3/1.0/en_us#greatwork/broadcaster_loci) at the given vector. If there is not a [Door](https://stick404.github.io/SlateWork/v/1.0.3/1.0/en_us#greatwork/broadcaster_loci), returns garbage. 
Does not mishap if casted outside of a [Spell Circle](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#greatwork/spellcircles), free, and does not require ambit.
This takes a number between 0 and 5 (inclusive), and sets the held slot of the bound [Pocket Simulator](https://stick404.github.io/SlateWork/v/1.0.3/1.0/en_us#greatwork/hotbar_loci). Free.

This returns all the items held within the [Pocket Simulator](https://stick404.github.io/SlateWork/v/1.0.3/1.0/en_us#greatwork/hotbar_loci) as [Item Stack Iotas](https://miyucomics.github.io/hexpose/v/1.0.0/1.0.0/en_us#patterns/scrying/item). Free.
Adds the current position of the Media Wave to the top of the stack.
Adds the current facing of the Media Wave to the top of the stack. If the current block does not have a facing, it returns a vector of [0,0,0].

Adds the current speed of the Media Wave to the top of the stack. This is measured in how many 20ths of a second the Media Wave waits until going to the next [Slate.](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/slate)
Adds the current amount of Media in the Impetus to the stack, in units of [dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).
Sets a list of players to be exclusively influenced by my special effects. If [Null](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#casting/influences), all can see my effects again.
Pushes the last sixteen unique sounds picked up by my [Microphone](https://miyucomics.github.io/special-efhexs/v/latest/main/en_us#items/microphone).
Plays a sound at a particular location, volume, and pitch. Costs about a sixteenth of an [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).
Pushes the last sixteen unique particles picked up by my [Microphone](https://miyucomics.github.io/special-efhexs/v/latest/main/en_us#items/microphone).

Conjures a particular particle with a specified position and velocity (blocks per twentieth of a second). Costs about 1/32th of an [Amethyst Dust](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/amethyst).
Conjures a small mote of dust of a given color. The number relates vaguely to scale and lifespan.
Conjures a gradient-like mote of dust, which smoothly transitions between the two colors given over the given number of seconds.
Conjures a visual bit of debris, similar to that caused by breaking a block. Takes in a block identifier.
Conjures particles similar to that caused by suspended gravity-affected blocks. Takes in a block identifier.
Conjures a visual bit of fragments, similar to that caused by a tool breaking after wearing. Takes in an item iota.
Conjures a blob of visible media, not unlike the waste product of my Hexes. Takes in a color.

Sends the iota on the top of the stack into the ether to be received by my current avatar. Can fail for [various reasons](https://penguinencounter.github.io/mediatransport/v/1.1.0+1.20.1/2.0/en_us#interop/figura/mishaps). Always costs a fixed 1 'sending power.'

Sends the iota on the top of the stack to be received by the player second from the top of the stack. It seems to have a separate receiver from the other one. Usually costs 2 'sending power', but this could be different depending on the server configuration.
Retrieves the next iota from the inbound queue, or [mishaps](https://penguinencounter.github.io/mediatransport/v/1.1.0+1.20.1/2.0/en_us#interop/figura/mishaps) if the queue is empty.
Queries the number of iotas in the queue.
Queries the amount of 'sending power' remaining.

Asks Nature to send information about its preferences to my current avatar. Costs 1 'spending power'. See [the protocol documentation](https://penguinencounter.github.io/mediatransport/v/1.1.0+1.20.1/2.0/en_us#mediatransport_virtual/protocol) for details.

To use [Consideration](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/patterns_as_iotas@hexcasting:escape), I draw it, then another arbitrary pattern. That second pattern is added to the stack.

Drawing [Introspection](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/patterns_as_iotas@hexcasting:open_paren) makes my drawing of patterns act differently, for a time. Until I draw [Retrospection](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/patterns_as_iotas@hexcasting:open_paren), the patterns I draw are saved. Then, when I draw [Retrospection](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/patterns_as_iotas@hexcasting:close_paren), they are added to the stack as a list iota.

If I draw another [Introspection](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/patterns_as_iotas@hexcasting:close_paren), it'll still be saved to the list, but I'll then have to draw *two* [Retrospections](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/patterns_as_iotas@hexcasting:close_paren) to get back to normal casting.

Finally, if I make a mistake while drawing patterns inside [Intro-](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/patterns_as_iotas@hexcasting:open_paren) and [Retrospection](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/patterns_as_iotas@hexcasting:close_paren) I can draw [Evanition](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#patterns/patterns_as_iotas@hexcasting:undo) to remove the last pattern that I drew from the pattern list that is being constructed.

operator.description: Irritatingly, there is no easy way to draw numbers. Here is the method Nature deigned to give us.
An infinite family of actions that keep or remove elements at the top of the stack based on the sequence of dips and lines.
Pops a pattern or pattern list and dives down an amount corresponding to the tail length to cast the pattern list. Useful for surgery-like operations.
Voids the entire stack except for the top n iota, determined by tail length. In the examples above, zero, one, and two iota are left untouched respectively.
Yanks the iota n from the top up to the top, determined by tail length. In the examples above, the iota second, third, and fourth from the top are yanked respectively.
Sinks the top iota n from the top, determined by tail length. In the examples above, the iota is moved to the second, third, and fourth place from the top respectively.

Just like with normal numbers, Nature is not so generous as to make this easy for us.
(Details on next page)

The starting cumulative number is 0; putting the initial direction to →, all ↗ makes the result **\* 2 + 1**, all → makes it **\* 2**, and all ↘ for **/ 10**. Starting with the patterns on the right negates the result.
Applies the given trace to the top Iota.

hexcasting:basics.name: Getting Started
hexcasting:basics.description: The practitioners of this art would cast their so-called Hexes by drawing strange patterns in the air with a [Staff](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/staff) -- or craft [powerful magical items](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/hexcasting) to do the casting for them. How might I do the same?

hexcasting:lapisworks.name: Lapisworks
hexcasting:lapisworks.description: I have found a seemingly obscure branch of Hex Casting, "Lapisworks". All of their texts are blank, but some outsider texts about the branch say they are encrypted with a "deep blue, precious mineral".

hexcasting:casting.name: Hex Casting
hexcasting:casting.description: I've started to understand how the old masters cast their Hexes! It's a bit complicated, but I'm sure I can figure it out. Let's see...

hexcasting:lapisworks/imbuement.name: Imbuement
hexcasting:lapisworks/imbuement.description: Despite Lapisworks being primarily focused on the enhancement of the body, some people have found ways to use it to enhance tools as well. Apparently some of the materials of this world have differing interactions with media. Let's see..

hexcasting:hexparse/commands.name: HexParse Commands
hexcasting:hexparse/commands.description: How I make use of the exotic power of HexParse.

hexcasting:lapisworks/great.name: The Wizard's Spells
hexcasting:lapisworks/great.description: Some intellectuals and/or adventurers saved the old wizard's diaries. I've begun to divine some of the wizard's knowledge from these ancient tomes.

hexcasting:lapisworks/interop.name: Interop
hexcasting:lapisworks/interop.description: The branch of Lapisworks has no problem interoperating with any other addons that I have installed on my world.

hexcasting:lamp.name: Genie Lamp
hexcasting:lamp.description: I have heard some tales from the villagers about a magical artifact. The villagers say it contains a spirit that grants wishes, but I suspect that is just grand embellishment evolved over centuries of storytelling. However, legends must arise from something and this item must be exceptionally powerful, and so I dedicate this section to my pursuit and research of it.

hexcasting:items.name: Items
hexcasting:items.description: I devote this section to the magical and mysterious items I might encounter in my studies.

hexcasting:greatwork.name: The Great Work
hexcasting:greatwork.description: I have seen... so much. I have... experienced... annihilation and deconstruction and reconstruction. I have seen the atoms of the world screaming as they were inverted and subverted and demoted to energy. I have seen I have seen I have s||get stick bugged lmao||

hexcasting:lore.name: Lore
hexcasting:lore.description: I have uncovered some letters and text not of direct relevance to my art. But, I think I may be able to divine some of the history of the world from these. Let me see...

hexcasting:interop.name: Cross-Mod Compatibility
hexcasting:interop.description: It appears I have installed some mods Hexcasting interoperates with! I've detailed them here.

hexcasting:creative_unlocker.name: The Media Cube
hexcasting:creative_unlocker.description: I have found a source of near limitless power, The Media Cube.

hexcasting:interop/figura.name: Figura
hexcasting:interop/figura.description: It appears that these constructs called avatars are quite powerful, if a bit annoying to work with.

hexcasting:patterns.name: Patterns
hexcasting:patterns.description: A list of all the patterns I've discovered, as well as what they do.

hexcasting:scrying.name: Scrying
hexcasting:scrying.description:
I have stumbled upon a branch of manipulating media entirely focused around information about the world.
While likely not useful for the majority of Hexes, these will be convenient to have, should I ever need them.

hexcasting:patterns/maths.name: Complex Mathematics
hexcasting:patterns/maths.description: This is a collection of transcripts from a (now defunct) "Mathematics Corps". I'm not sure what use these have, but I *would* like to know what the researchers were on whilst writing them.

hexcasting:patterns/spells.name: Spells
hexcasting:patterns/spells.description: Patterns and actions that perform a magical effect on the world.

hexcasting:patterns/great_spells.name: Great Spells
hexcasting:patterns/great_spells.description:
The spells catalogued here are purported to be of legendary difficulty and power. They seem to have been recorded only [sparsely](https://hexcasting.hexxy.media/v/0.11.2/1.0/en_us#items/scroll) (for good reason, the texts claim). It's probably just the ramblings of extinct traditionalists, though -- a pattern's a pattern.
What could possibly go wrong?

hexcasting:patterns/grand.name: Grand Spells
hexcasting:patterns/grand.description: It appears that there is another layer of spells. I must infuse my will inorder to find them. I will document what I find out about them here

hexcasting:patterns/grand/mindflay_ritua.name: Mass Mindflay Rituals
hexcasting:patterns/grand/mindflay_ritua.description:
Here I have compiled every rituals known to me.
"On The Bulk Flaying Of Minds"

Seems to operate on a "Point" system. with each villager being worth double the previous

hexcasting:mediatransport_admin_virtual.name: mediatransport admin
hexcasting:mediatransport_admin_virtual.description: This category is **hexdoc only** (not in in-game book) and contains information for server administrators installing mediatransport and FSB.

hexcasting:lapisworks_patterns#lapiswork.title: Imbue Lapis
hexcasting:lapisworks_patterns#lapiswork.text: Transform all the Lapis Lazuli in my other hand into a loosely-held material called Amethyst Lazuli or Amel for short. Costs twice the number of Amethyst Shards as Lapis Lazuli in my offhand.

hexcasting:lapisworks_patterns#lapiswork.title: Reclaim Amethyst
hexcasting:lapisworks_patterns#lapiswork.text: Transform all the Amethyst Lazuli in my other hand into Amethyst Shards. The Lapis turns into a fine mist which spreads quickly in the air. Excess shards spill onto the ground. Costs one Amethyst Shard.

hexcasting:lapisworks_patterns#lapiswork.title: Mold Amel
hexcasting:lapisworks_patterns#lapiswork.text: While I could shape Amel into whatever I want, I have decided on four primary shapes which are familiar to me. I can use this pattern to mold the Amel in my offhand for free.

hexcasting:lapisworks_patterns#lapiswork.title: Enchant Skin
hexcasting:lapisworks_patterns#lapiswork.text: Pass in an entity and a number of half-hearts, and it enchants that entity's skin thus increasing their health. The Amel cost is the number given and the cost in media is twice the expended Amel.

hexcasting:lapisworks_patterns#lapiswork.title: Enchant Fists
